Titular: Newmont ups dividend by 79 per cent as gold prices surge
Subtitular: Pledge by world’s largest gold miner comes as metal nears 7-year high
Texto: Newmont will increase its quarterly dividend by 79 per cent, the world’s largest gold miner said on Monday, as gold prices surged toward a seven-year high.The Colorado-based miner said its dividend would rise to 25 cents a share starting in the quarter ending April 2020, or $1 a share on an annualised basis.Gold hit its highest level since April 2013 on Monday, of $1,579.72 a troy ounce, due to rising tensions in the Middle East following the US assassination of a top Iranian general in Iraq.Newmont also said it will continue its stock buyback plan, with a target to buy back $1bn worth of equity. In the quarter ending December 31, Newmont spent $506m buying back shares, it said.Shares in Newmont rose 1.3 per cent to $43.39 in morning trading on the news.

Titular: Newmont offers special dividend to shareholders to back Goldcorp transaction
Texto: Newmont Mining has offered a special dividend to its shareholders to win their approval for its coming $10bn takeover of Canadian gold miner Goldcorp, following public opposition by two large investors.Newmont said its large shareholders had made it clear they wanted to receive the benefits of a recent joint venture announcement with Barrick Gold in Nevada rather than Goldcorp shareholders.Last week both New York hedge fund Paulson & Co and fund management group Van Eck said they would not support the Goldcorp transaction unless the agreed 17 per cent premium was eliminated.“We are pleased to make this special dividend payable to Newmont’s current shareholders in recognition of the potential synergy value of the Nevada joint venture agreement,” Gary Goldberg, Newmont’s chief executive, said. “We have continued to engage with, and have listened carefully to, our shareholders, and we are pleased that several of our largest shareholders have expressed their support for the combination with Goldcorp.”The dividend of 88 cents a share will be paid to all Newmont shareholders as of April 17, and is conditional upon them approving the Goldcorp transaction in shareholder votes next month. It will be paid on May 1, Newmont said.A spokesman for Paulson & Co said they are “currently evaluating the announcement.”Newmont fended off a hostile acquisition attempt by Barrick Gold this month by agreeing to form a joint venture with the Canadian miner in Nevada, where they both have big operations, instead.Barrick had attempted to take over Newmont and thwart its planned acquisition of Goldcorp.Once the largest gold producer in the world Vancouver-based Goldcorp has struggled over the past few years with its shares down by over 70 per cent since 2011.

Titular: Second major investor opposes Newmont-Goldcorp merger
Texto: VanEck, one of the largest investors in Newmont Mining, has become the second investor to call on the gold miner to reduce the premium it is paying in its $10bn acquisition of rival Goldcorp.New York-based fund manager Joe Foster said Newmont was giving too much value to Goldcorp shareholders following a tie-up with Barrick Gold in Nevada, which was agreed this month.“The Nevada JV [between] Newmont and Barrick did not exist when the Goldcorp deal was announced,” he said. “That is creating a lot of value for shareholders. The Goldcorp shareholders are not entitled to that value, it’s not in the deal price.”Van Eck’s statement comes a day after New York hedge fund Paulson & Co called on Newmont to reduce the 17 per cent premium it agreed to pay to acquire Goldcorp in January.Shareholders for both companies will vote on the deal next month.Newmont fended off a hostile acquisition attempt by Barrick Gold this month by agreeing to form a joint venture with the Canadian miner in Nevada instead.Barrick had attempted to take over Newmont and thwart its planned acquisition of Goldcorp.Once the largest gold producer in the world, Vancouver-based Goldcorp has struggled over the past few years with its shares down by over 70 per cent since 2011. Newmont has argued that it can run Goldcorp’s mines better and find more gold.Mr Foster said he was also opposed to a planned payout for Goldcorp’s chairman Ian Telfer if the deal goes through. Mr Telfer’s retirement allowance is set to increase to $12m from $4.5m after the acquisition.“It just puts a black mark on the industry when you see stuff like that happening,” Mr Foster said.Shares in Goldcorp fell by 3.4 per cent in Toronto to C$14.43.

Titular: John Paulson says he opposes Newmont Mining’s merger with Goldcorp
Texto: New York hedge fund Paulson & Co said it opposes Newmont Mining’s planned $10bn acquisition of Canada’s Goldcorp, saying it shouldn’t reward Goldcorp shareholders by paying a premium.John Paulson, one of the largest investors in the gold sector, said it was “unable to support the transaction” unless the premium was eliminated since all the benefits of a recent tie-up with Barrick Gold in Nevada would accrue to Goldcorp shareholders.“We believe that in order for this combination to add value for Newmont shareholders, it must be renegotiated to eliminate the premium paid and the sharing of the Nevada synergies,” Mr Paulson said in a letter to Newmont’s chief executive Gary Goldberg.The letter comes just a week after Newmont fended off a hostile acquisition attempt by rival Barrick Gold by agreeing to form a joint venture with the Canadian miner in Nevada.Barrick had attempted to take over Newmont and thwart its planned acquisition of Goldcorp, which was announced in January.Paulson, which said it owns 14.2m shares of Newmont Mining, said Goldcorp shareholders should receive 0.254 in Newmont shares in the deal rather than the agreed 0.328 of Newmont shares.When it was announced in January the deal represented a premium of 17 per cent over Goldcorp’s 20-day volume weighted average share price.“At this level, the transaction would generate value for Newmont shareholders, while providing Goldcorp shareholders attractive consideration and an opportunity to participate in the shared upside of the combined company,” Mr Paulson said.Mr Paulson has been one of the most active gold investors in recent years, and was one of the leading fund managers behind the formation of a Shareholders’ Gold Council last year designed to boost the performance of gold miners.Mr Paulson rose to fame after the financial crisis, when Paulson & Co made billions of dollars from predicting the US housing crisis.

Titular: New York’s Four Seasons plays home to a gold mining deal
Subtitular: Welcome to Due Diligence, the FT’s daily deals briefing
Texto: FT premium subscribers can click here to receive Due Diligence every day by email.A DD scoop to start: Rupert Murdoch’s News Corp, Germany’s Axel Springer and the world’s largest rating agencies are among the list of companies set to enter a bidding war for Acuris, the owner of Mergermarket, as the auction gets under way this week. A number of companies have thrown their hat into the ring and while it’s too early to tell which group is in pole position, DD will keep you posted. Now back to the show . . .It may be in a new spot. Its longtime maître’d may have been ousted. But New York’s Four Seasons Restaurant still manages to be the destination where power brokers come to broker deals.The latest example came last Tuesday when Barrick Gold’s chief executive Mark Bristow stopped by to break bread with Newmont Mining boss Gary Goldberg.This was no ordinary gathering. The two gold mining executives were locked in a nasty war of words with the future of the industry at stake. Days earlier, Barrick launched a hostile $18bn, nil-premium, all-share bid to buy Newmont. The deal would create the world’s largest gold producer.Newmont rejected the bid. It countered with a proposal to form a joint venture in Nevada where the companies have assets that sit side by side. The prospect of combining their Nevada holdings hold out the possibility of some of the easiest synergies to unlock in the mining business, if they can get beyond two decades of rivalry and flirtation over a deal.The JV offer provided enough cover for Bristow, a tough-talking, big game huntin’ South African, to huddle with Goldberg, an American who graduated from Rio Tinto’s Top Gun mining school — a sort of miner’s miner — over dinner.Newmont said the talks were constructive, but DD was sceptical. Shareholders wanted the two sides to resolve matters, and the tough talk seemed personal and the egos involved massive. Those aren’t the sort of conditions that lead to a healthy, positive outcome. Get smart on the background and the characters by reading last Friday’s DD briefing.Yet on Monday, we learnt just how constructive the talks were. The two companies unveiled a joint venture that allowed both sides to walk away claiming victory.Barrick will take a 61.5 per cent stake in a joint venture company, with Newmont holding the remainder. As a standalone business, it’ll be the world’s biggest producer of gold with 4.1m ounces of production a year.Bristow will have the luxury of running the combined mine, while Goldberg gets to cement his planned $10bn takeover of Goldcorp, which will make Newmont the biggest gold company in the world.Happy ending, right? Now the two sides have to prove that they can actually work together. The titanic egos were on show as Bristow and Goldberg tried to claim credit for the breakthrough and argue that they got the better end of the transaction. Scratch beneath the surface of this deal and a number of thorny issues remain.That made DD think of this valedictory piece by our outgoing business editor Sarah Gordon, which is a drop everything, print out and keep must read, if you haven’t already.Sarah talks about her two decades writing about business for the FT and the egomaniacs that manage to convince themselves they’re value-creating gurus.The good news for Barrick and Newmont shareholders is that no money is changing hands; no stock is being issued for their JV deal.China’s internet and gaming giant Tencent has stakes in more than 700 companies across the world and holds board seats on more than 400 of them. About 30-40 per cent of its investments are outside China. The value of its portfolio is estimated at about $70bn — approaching the size of SoftBank’s far higher-profile Vision Fund.In just three years, Tencent has become one of China’s top overseas investors. Read more at the FT here.“Many people asked us if we are going to reduce our level of investments this year,” said Martin Lau, Tencent’s president, at a recent investor day. “I tell everyone right now. We will not do this.”But some venture capital insiders are starting to question Tencent’s endgame: is it building a massive ecosystem across its investments, or have its investment banker leaders gone too far?Companies in China often welcome the investment as a way to grab rapid market share. Tencent offers them the chance to reach more than a billion users. To achieve scale, they need either the Shenzhen-based company or its eastern Chinese rival Alibaba, especially in areas such as ecommerce. “It’s almost impossible to succeed in China retail without Alibaba or Tencent,” said James Root, a Hong Kong-based partner at Bain & Co.In this way Tencent is stitching together what appears to be a massive ecosystem of companies, services and technologies. By taking in investment from the company you become part of that universe, or so the argument goes.Some observers, though, are questioning how concerted the Tencent ecosystem really is, and have acknowledged that it is beginning to look like the work of investment bankers gone wild. Before joining Tencent, Lau was an M&A banker at Goldman Sachs, and James Mitchell, his chief strategy officer, worked as an equity analyst at the US bank.“When you put a basketball player in the room, you know what they’re going to do,” shrugged one venture capital investor. “If you hire Goldman Sachs bankers, you know what they are going to do.”At this point, some of the same criticisms aimed at the Vision Fund — reckless levels of investment that’ll be hard to gain returns on — can be applied to Tencent.Last week we introduced you to the key players deciding the future of Germany’s embattled Deutsche Bank (in case you need a refresh click here). Over the weekend we discovered that Christian Sewing, the chief executive of the once mighty bank, has dropped his opposition to considering a merger with domestic lender rival Commerzbank. Below are a few key charts giving us a better picture of what’s driving these two together.It’s a matter of size: both are lagging behind the rest in terms of price-to-book value as well return on equity.Deutsche Bank has underperformed the rest of the industry, driven by a wave of bad news.Revenues have been on a persistent decline.And costs are higher than at other European rivals.Interested in reading more?We have a deep dive looking at the how we got here; a new article on how regulators are concerned that Deutsche lacks the “ruthless brutality” to execute a successful merger, a Lex column analysing the merits of a deal and an FT editorial board piece explaining why the deal might go against EU bail-in rules.Bank of America Merrill Lynch has appointed James Robertson and Peter Luck as co-heads of UK investment banking in London. Robertson is joining the bank from UBS while Luck has been building out Bank of America’s corporate broking franchise in Emea since joining in 2012.Takumi Shibata is stepping down as president and chief executive of Nikko Asset Management after becoming embroiled in a US lawsuit over incentives. It’s Shibata’s second high-profile resignation after leaving his role as chief operating officer of Nomura Holdings in 2012 in the wake of an insider trading scandal. More here.Jan Stahlberg, a co-founder of EQT and veteran of Europe’s private equity industry, has left Scandinavia’s biggest private equity group to set up his own fund. Stahlberg has raised €300m-€500m from the bank Nordea to pursue so-called impact investing and is expected to attract other institutional investors. More here.Loek van den Boog is returning to his role as special adviser to General Atlantic 15 years after he left the private equity firm. The former chairman of Mendix and Myriad supported the group as a special adviser for eight years between 1996 and 2004.Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe has hired Robyn Helmlinger as a partner in the law firm’s public finance group. Helmlinger, who will be based in San Francisco, joins the firm from Squire Patton Boggs where she led their healthcare finance initiative.RBC has hired the former chief executive of BNY Mellon Markets, Michelle Neal, to head up its US fixed income business. Neal will be responsible for expanding the bank’s fixed-income business and will report to Jonathan Hunter, the global head of fixed income.Katten Muchin Rosenman has hired Michelle Gyves as a partner in its private equity practice. Gyves was previously an associate at Proskauer Rose in New York.Derek Zaba has left his role as head of contested situations at PJT Camberview, to join law firm Sidley Austin in the summer as a partner and co-head of its activism defence practice, Reuters reports.Bond king Bill Gross opens up to the FT’s Robin Wigglesworth about the good, the bad and the ugly including his epic rise and subsequent defenestration at Pimco, failing in the Navy, his Asperger’s diagnosis and a nasty (smelling) divorce. (FT)Aping activists Wellington Management’s public denunciation of the $90bn merger between Bristol-Myers Squibb and Celgene could prove a turning point for stockpicking firms as they struggle to compete with cheaper passive investment strategies, reports DD’s James Fontanella-Khan. (FT)Fashion victim Not even the return of LK Bennett’s founder could save the struggling fashion retailer that popularised the kitten heel as it grappled with high rents, high prices and low customer demand. (FT)Breaking the dress code When Goldman Sachs sneezes, Wall Street catches a cold. The FT’s Robert Armstrong captures Wall Street’s reaction to a dressed down Goldman Sachs. (FT)Nvidia to acquire Israeli chipmaker Mellanox for $6.9bn (FT)OneSavings/CCFS: buy-to-sweat (FT)Advent drops bid for Italian credit manager Cerved (FT)Ghosn seeks court permission to attend Nissan board meeting (FT)Newcrest shrugs off impact of consolidation in gold industry (FT)Railroad owner Genesee & Wyoming is exploring a stake sale (BBG)UK accounting watchdog to be replaced by stronger regulator (FT)HNA/Blackstone: flash dance (FT)US financiers consider selling stake in Crystal Palace football club (FT)Interserve’s banks line up pre-pack administration (FT)Boeing shares in worst fall since 2001 after Ethiopian crash (FT)Southwest shares knocked by Ethiopian Airlines crash fallout (FT)Ryanair and KT face stock turmoil over removal from indices (FT)Plastic packager RPC agrees to higher £3.3bn bid from Berry (FT)Elliott wins ISS support for board shake-up at Hyundai Motor (BBG)Due Diligence is written by Arash Massoudi, Javier Espinoza and Robert Smith in London, James Fontanella-Khan, Ortenca Aliaj, Sujeet Indap, Eric Platt, Jennifer Bissell-Linsk, Lindsay Fortado and Mark Vandevelde in New York, and Don Weinland in Hong Kong.FT premium subscribers can sign up here. Titular: Barrick Gold drops $18bn hostile bid for Newmont
Subtitular: Gold producers agree to create joint venture from duo’s Nevada mines
Texto: Barrick Gold has dropped an $18bn hostile bid for Newmont Mining after agreeing a deal to combine operations in the US state of Nevada.Under the deal, Barrick will operate a new joint venture company and take a 61.5 per cent stake, with Newmont holding the remainder. As a standalone business, it will be the world’s biggest producer of gold, with 4.1m ounces of production a year.The deal marks the end of a fierce bid battle by Barrick that descended into each side attacking the other’s management. It also caps 20 years of efforts by the two rival companies to work together in Nevada.On Monday, both companies rushed to claim victory for the creation of the partnership, which had originally been proposed by Newmont.Mark Bristow, Barrick’s South African chief executive, said the two sides had come to an agreement after he had dinner with Gary Goldberg, Newmont’s chief executive, at the Four Seasons in New York on Tuesday. That progressed to talks in Toronto on Thursday and an agreement that was signed in Elko, Nevada, on Sunday, he said.“I’ve managed to convince Gary that this was a do-able thing and he got to the same point very quickly,” Mr Bristow told the Financial Times. “It’s a completely deliverable transaction.”Mr Bristow said the deal would create value for Barrick shareholders without “issuing a single share”.Last week Newmont formally rejected Barrick’s all-share bid, with Mr Goldberg calling it “egocentric”. It countered with a proposal for a joint venture with a 55 per cent share for Barrick, which Mr Bristow also quickly dismissed.“Nevada JV is not the right path forward,” Barrick said in a hastily assembled presentation at the time.But the mood changed after some of Newmont and Barrick’s largest shareholders indicated their preference for a joint venture over a takeover of Newmont. Barrick has only just completed its $6bn acquisition of Randgold and some shareholders worried that another deal would be taking on too much, too quickly.Tom Palmer, Newmont’s incoming chief, who will take over from Mr Goldberg this year, said the deal came about due to the encouragement of the company’s shareholders.“I think it was the combination of us putting out a constructive proposal to realise the synergies that everyone knew were there in Nevada, and listening to shareholders,” he said.The two sides agreed on the ownership split based on the valuation ascribed to the assets by analysts, he added. Barrick will have three seats on the board and Newmont two.Mr Bristow won a victory by becoming the operator of the joint venture. Newmont had previously proposed that key management roles be jointly appointed.Barrick and Newmont said the venture would generate an estimated $500m in annual pre-tax synergies in its first five full years.Other terms of the deal, which were criticised by Mr Bristow a week ago, have not materially changed.Barrick’s increased shareholding reflects the fact that Newmont has not included its Cripple Creek & Victor gold mine in Colorado, which was included in its original proposal.Also not included is Barrick’s Fourmile exploration asset in Nevada, which can be placed in the joint venture if it meets certain targets.Mr Bristow refused to say whether this had been Barrick’s plan all along. “At the end of the day, we have reached an agreement,” he said.

Titular: Barrick chief faces test of credentials and time
Subtitular: Mark Bristow has an uphill battle to win over Newmont shareholders
Texto: Mark Bristow is in a race against time as he tries to create a gold mining colossus worth $40bn through a merger of Barrick Gold, the company he runs, with its arch rival Newmont Mining.In a month’s time Newmont shareholders will vote on a $10bn takeover of Vancouver-based Goldcorp. If they approve the deal, it would in effect make the US miner bid proof and stifle Mr Bristow’s plan to create “the world’s best gold company”.It promises to be a hard fought contest as both sides try to rally support in the next few weeks from a core group of key shareholders who have large stakes in both companies. These include BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, New York-based Van Eck, and Germany’s Flossbach von Storch.To succeed, Mr Bristow will not only have to persuade Newmont shareholders to vote down the Goldcorp deal — which he said was “ill-conceived” and unlikely to deliver significant benefits — but also convince them he can run a merged Barrick-Newmont. It will be no easy task.Newmont has already knocked back Mr Bristow’s $18bn hostile offer and countered with a proposal to combine the two producers’ lucrative Nevada operations in a joint venture. That plan has already received the backing of some investors who are sceptical of megamergers because of a history of wasteful deals in the mining industry, including Barrick’s $7.3bn purchase of copper miner Equinox in 2011.“We know there’s a lot of value to be created in Nevada and there’s an opportunity here to create value by doing a JV so that’s my first choice,” said Joe Foster, a fund manager at New York-based Van Eck, which is the biggest shareholder in Barrick and owns a 5.9 per cent stake in Newmont.Newmont is also prepared to play dirty. This week it released private email correspondence from 2017 in which Mr Bristow praised Goldcorp’s “strong portfolio” of assets in “world-class districts”.At the same time, it has attacked Mr Bristow’s record at Randgold Resources, the Africa-focused gold miner he co-founded and sold to Barrick last year.“There is no doubt that Mark has been successful as an explorer and a geologist,” Gary Goldberg, Newmont chief executive, told analysts this week. “As an operator, he has not created shareholder value, and he has yet to prove that he can successfully manage or integrate a global portfolio.”But Mr Bristow, a straight-talking South African who likes to hunt big game, is not easily intimidated. “We are definitely not going to withdraw our offer,” he said.The battle between Barrick and Newmont comes as the gold industry tries to revive its fortunes after being shunned by investors who have grown tired of the sector’s lacklustre returns, profligate spending and excessive executive pay.The $6bn acquisition of London-listed Randgold by Barrick last year raised the prospect of further consolidation in a sector where there are multiple mid-sized gold producers.Combining Barrick and Newmont would create a company with more than 10m ounces of production from mines on five continents around the world.The two rivals have been circling each other for decades and came close to a deal in 2014, but the talks collapsed because of disagreements over governance roles and where to locate a head office.Those old rivalries have been quick to resurface with Barrick’s nil-premium offer unleashing a bitter war of words between the two companies.Mr Goldberg described Barrick’s all-share bid as “desperate and bizarre”, while Mr Bristow claimed he could run Newmont better than its current executives.Mr Bristow also questioned whether Newmont really wants to do a deal in Nevada, or is playing for time as its attempt to push through the Goldcorp deal.“Newmont’s latest proposal is essentially based on the stale and convoluted process that foundered previously. As usual, it comes with unrealistic preconditions including swapping the chairmanship and the leadership of the JV,” said Mr Bristow. “Experience has shown us that JVs only work well when the majority owner is also the operator.”The state of Nevada, where both companies have neighbouring operations, is the focal point of Barrick’s bid, accounting for more than two-thirds of the projected annual synergies of $750m.Mr Bristow has said a deal for Newmont could unlock another 20 years of profitable gold production in the state.“That’s where most of the value is created in the short term. It’s probably the key to determining where this gets to,” said Alasdair McKinnon, a fund manager at the Scottish Investment Trust and a Newmont shareholder.Tom Palmer, Newmont’s incoming chief executive who previously worked at Rio Tinto, said the Goldcorp takeover and a Nevada JV are not mutually exclusive and its shareholders can benefit from both.He said the proposal for Barrick to have 55 per cent of the JV and Newmont 45 per cent was not set in stone and could be adjusted.“For us it’s a starting point to get people to the table,” Mr Palmer said.Mr Bristow — who believes a 63-37 per cent split is more equitable — discussed the proposal over dinner with Mr Goldberg in New York on Tuesday night.However, key to the bid battle could be BlackRock. The world’s largest asset manager is also the biggest shareholder in Newmont. Some of its 15 per cent stake held by BlackRock is managed by Evy Hambro, one of the most influential mining investors in the world. BlackRock declined to comment.Some analysts and investors have said that if the miners cannot reach terms on a JV, Barrick may need to pay a premium to secure Newmont.“We doubt a zero premium is likely to persuade Newmont shareholders. Although a premium [in cash] might be successful,” said Mathew Hocking, analyst at JPMorgan.While Mr Bristow has ruled that out for now, the hard-driving miner knows the clock is ticking.“Time is of the essence,” he added.

Titular: Newmont Mining says initial talks with Barrick ‘constructive’
Subtitular: Chief executives meet to discuss Nevada joint venture over dinner
Texto: Newmont Mining said initial talks with rival Barrick Gold on a joint venture in Nevada, which could generate hundreds of millions of dollars in cost savings, had been “constructive”.Tom Palmer, who will take over the US gold miner this year, said a dinner between Newmont’s chief executive Gary Goldberg and Barrick’s Mark Bristow in New York on Tuesday was a starting point to work out a deal.“We’re very genuine about putting on the table a draft JV term sheet,” Mr Palmer told the Financial Times ahead of meetings with leading shareholders in London. “To get a resolution, to exercise value for shareholders.”The comments come after Colorado-based Newmont rejected an $18bn hostile bid by Canada’s Barrick on Monday, offering instead a proposal for a joint venture in Nevada, where both companies have sizeable operations.Newmont is attempting to win support for its $10bn acquisition of Canadian gold miner Goldcorp, which will be voted on next month by shareholders.Mr Palmer said Newmont’s initial proposal for Barrick to have 55 per cent of the joint venture and Newmont 45 per cent was just a starting point for discussions.Mr Bristow rejected Newmont’s proposal this week, saying it did not reflect the value of Barrick’s assets in the US state of Nevada.Mr Palmer claimed Mr Bristow and Barrick had since had time to reflect on the proposal.“For us it’s a starting point to get people to the table,” he said.“By the end of the day I think there’s been a bit of reflection and appropriate consideration of what has been proposed,” he said.If the two sides were not able to reach an agreement on a joint venture in Nevada, Mr Palmer said Newmont would be prepared to publish a detailed study on the potential costs savings.“If necessary, yes,” he said.Van Eck, a top five shareholder in Barrick and Newmont, said on Tuesday that a study would allow investors to decide the best way forward if discussions between Barrick and Newmont reached an impasse.Asked why Newmont and Barrick have not combined operations in Nevada, one of the largest sources of gold in the world, before Mr Palmer said it was because there had not been a party “sitting across the table” willing to talk.Some analysts and investors believe the joint venture proposal is a tactic to divert Barrick’s attention while it tries to push through its takeover of Goldcorp.But Mr Palmer said it was a genuine proposal and the best way forward was the acquisition of Goldcorp and a JV with Barrick.“You can have both,” Mr Palmer said.Mr Palmer said Newmont had filed a draft proxy statement with the US Securities and Exchange Commission and expected a vote on the Goldcorp deal to happen in mid to late April.He said that he had put a “compelling argument” on the Goldcorp transaction and JV to shareholders this week, including BlackRock, the largest shareholder of Newmont.

Titular: Barrick’s biggest shareholder calls for JV with Newmont
Subtitular: Van Eck says rival goldminers should publish joint study of benefits and let shareholders decide
Texto: One of the biggest shareholders in Barrick Gold and Newmont Mining has called on the two companies to agree a joint venture in Nevada that could generate hundreds of millions of dollars in cost savings.New York-based Van Eck said if the two bitter rivals could not reach an agreement they should publish a detailed study of the benefits and let shareholders decide.Joe Foster, fund manager at Van Eck, told the Financial Times, “We know there’s a lot of value to be created in Nevada and there’s an opportunity here to create value by doing a JV so that’s my first choice.”The comments from Van Eck come as the chief executives of Barrick and Newmont meet in New York for discussions on a JV, a day after Newmont rejected Barrick’s audacious $18bn hostile bid for the company.“If these two adversaries cannot come to terms on Nevada, we call on them to prioritise their shareholder’s interests by publishing a joint definitive feasibility study that quantifies the value and articulates plans to unlock it,” Mr Foster said. “Once this is done, the best path forward should become obvious.”While Mr Foster did not say he would oppose Barrick’s bid for Newmont, he did question the logic of megamergers in the gold industry. Barrick completed its $6bn purchase of Randgold, the London-listed gold miner, in January.“In addition to the considerable skills needed to manage so many mines, it may be geologically impossible to sustain a gold company that is as large as these companies are becoming,” he said in an investor letter.Van Eck is one of a small group of shareholders with stakes in both companies that will be pivotal in determining whether Newmont merges with Barrick or instead completes its planned $10bn acquisition of Canadian gold miner Goldcorp.Newmont shareholders are due to vote in April on the Goldcorp deal, leaving Barrick chief executive Mark Bristow only a matter of weeks to convince shareholders of the merits of his bid.Although Mr Bristow has not ruled out a JV in Nevada, he said on Monday he was not sure it was the best way to proceed.“Nevada, with a combined 76m ounces, will be worth a whole lot more if it is run by one operator,” he said on Monday. “Experience has shown us that JVs only work well when the majority owner is also the operator,” he added.Newmont has suggested that a JV would be managed by both companies with ownership split 45 per cent for Newmont and 55 per cent for Barrick.Van Eck owns 5.9 per cent of Newmont and is Barrick’s biggest shareholder with a 6.3 per cent stake.Mr Foster said there could be “significant value to be gained from merging” the two companies’ Nevada operations. But shareholders do not have the data, resources or technical expertise to evaluate such a proposal, he added.

Titular: Emerging market debt burdens may be sorely understated
Subtitular: Recent paper suggests overseas liabilities of EMs are greater than previously thought
Texto: For emerging economies, coronavirus struck first through the financial markets. Long before the numbers of cases and deaths in these countries began to spread alarm, many emerging markets experienced a sudden halt in foreign investment inflows.Overseas investors have taken $95bn out of EM stocks and bonds since late January, according to the Institute of International Finance, dwarfing the withdrawals that followed the onset of the global financial crisis in September 2008.As Covid-19 infections rise and fragile health systems struggle to cope, foreign investors may be low on the list of concerns for EM governments. But these outflows will have a big impact on the fiscal measures policymakers can bring to bear on the crisis.Emerging markets’ overseas liabilities, moreover, may be bigger than previously imagined. A paper published by Matteo Maggiori at Stanford and colleagues at Harvard, Chicago Booth and Columbia Business School suggests the true ownership of EM bonds by overseas investors is much greater than shown in standard data — in some countries, by many multiples.The paper also suggests that foreign holdings of shares issued by Chinese companies may be many times greater than the $160bn that shows up in US national accounts. Should US-China relations sour in the aftermath of the coronavirus crisis, these giant holdings could become a source of significant risk.Mr Maggiori and his colleagues question the normal practice of allocating securities in national accounts on the basis of the residency rather than the nationality of their issuer. It may make sense, for example, for a bond issued by a Brazilian subsidiary of Banco Santander to be added to the debt statistics of Brazil (the residency of its issuer) rather than Spain (the nationality of the issuer’s ultimate owner), because the bond’s proceeds are likely to be put to use in Brazil.But it makes much less sense for a bond issued by Petrobras International Finance Company, a Cayman Island subsidiary of the Brazilian oil group, to be added to the debt statistics of the Cayman Islands. Yet that is what happens in standard, residency-based financial statistics such as the US’s Treasury International Capital data (TIC) and the IMF’s Coordinated Portfolio Investment Survey (CPIS).Mr Maggiori says this results in a vast understatement of the investments by US, European and other international investors in emerging economies. So the academics developed an algorithm to reallocate the securities logged in the TIC and CPIS data according to nationality rather than residency.The results are startling. TIC data show that US ownership of Brazilian bonds at the end of 2017 amounted to $8bn, based on the residency of issuers. But restated by nationality, the total rises to $68bn. For Chinese bonds, the total rises from $3bn to $55bn. Mr Maggiori says the results sound a warning as the coronavirus crisis threatens to tip emerging markets into a debt crisis.“If we are going to see a wave of corporate defaults, it’s a risk worth thinking about that a lot of issuance has taken place offshore,” he said. “[Our work] shows that exposures are quite large.”What is also striking is the role played by tax havens such as the Cayman Islands. In the TIC data, of Brazil’s $59bn in reallocated bonds, $42bn were issued in tax havens. Of China’s $52bn, $44bn were issued in tax havens. The results also shine a light on the role of so-called variable interest equity structures in US investments in Chinese companies. VIEs allow US investors to hold shares in these companies, circumventing Chinese restrictions on foreign ownership of some operating businesses. But in these transactions what investors actually buy are shares in listed companies, generally resident in the Cayman Islands, that give them a claim on the profits of Chinese operating businesses.By reallocating such investments on the basis of nationality rather than residence, the paper shows that US “ownership” of Chinese companies at the end of 2017 was not $160bn, as shown in US national statistics, but $700bn. This puts it closer to the amount of Chinese ownership of US Treasuries, of about $1.1tn. This is significant because Chinese regulators are certainly aware of the smoke-and-mirrors act being carried out by VIEs. They could, should they wish, bring the practice to an end.Mr Maggiori is not suggesting they will. But he thinks the risk is worth noting. “You read a lot about the possibility of China dumping its US Treasuries but very little about the possibility of China imposing its own regulations. If we’re talking about one, we should certainly be talking about the other,” he said.jonathan.wheatley@ft.com

Titular: Barrick and Newmont CEOs to meet in New York after rejected hostile bid
Texto: The chief executives of Barrick Gold and Newmont Mining will meet in New York on Tuesday to discuss a proposal for a joint venture following Newmont’s rejection of Barrick’s hostile $18bn bid for the gold mining company.Gary Goldberg, chief executive of Newmont, and Mark Bristow, chief executive of Barrick, will meet to discuss Mr Goldberg’s plans for a joint venture in Nevada, according to a person close to the companies.The meeting comes a day after Newmont formally rejected Barrick’s hostile all-stock nil-premium offer, with Mr Goldberg calling it “egocentric.”Newmont insisted its planned $10bn takeover of Canada’s Goldcorp was the best deal for shareholders. Newmont shareholders are set to vote on that deal in the second quarter of this year.Mr Goldberg instead proposed a JV in Nevada to capture the benefits that Barrick proposed in its bid. It would be managed by both companies with ownership split 45 per cent for Newmont and 55 per cent for Barrick.But Mr Bristow dismissed that idea on Monday, saying that JVs only work when the majority owner is also the operator and that Newmont’s proposal is “essentially based on the stale and convoluted process that foundered previously.”In an updated investor presentation on Tuesday, Barrick said Newmont’s deal with Goldcorp would dilute the quality of Newmont’s assets.It argued that a merger between Barrick and Newmont would give shareholders over three times the exposure to “Tier One” gold assets.

Titular: Barrick chief says willing to talk with Newmont over Nevada
Subtitular: Time of the essence, says Mark Bristow after $18bn bid rejected
Texto: Barrick Gold’s chief Mark Bristow said he’s willing to talk to rival Newmont about a deal to work together in Nevada but Barrick had to run the operations.Mr Bristow said he will soon send a formal invitation to Newmont’s chief executive Gary Goldberg for discussions, following Newmont’s rejection of Barrick’s hostile $18bn bid for the company on Monday.“My suggestion is that Gary gets his team up here tomorrow,” Mr Bristow told the Financial Times. “Time is of the essence.”Newmont said on Monday that it had rejected Barrick’s hostile bid for the company and that a joint venture in Nevada, where both companies have substantial operations, makes more sense.Newmont proposed a JV structure for Nevada that would be managed by both companies with ownership split 45 per cent for Newmont and 55 per cent for Barrick.But Mr Bristow said that JV’s only work when the majority owner is also the operator and that Newmont’s proposal is “essentially based on the stale and convoluted process that foundered previously.”“You need to have one person responsible and in control,” Mr Bristow said. “We are not fund managers, we are not allocators of capital. We are drivers of value and deliverables as a business.”Earlier talks in 2014 between Barrick and Newmont to co-operate in Nevada broke down after both sides failed to agree on terms for a JV.Mr Bristow questioned whether Newmont was being “genuine” with its proposal or just trying to buy time while it attempted to push through its $10bn acquisition of Goldcorp.Mr Bristow asked why Newmont had included the 360,000-ounce-a-year Cripple Creek & Victor mine in Colorado in the Nevada JV and if the proposed 55-45 per cent split was fair.“I don’t believe Colorado is part of Nevada,” said Mr Bristow. “If you look at consensus valuation [of the Nevada assets] the split should be more 63 per cent and 37 per cent.”Newmont says it sends gold concentrate from CC&V to a mill in Nevada because it has a high sulphur content, which provides fuel for a processing technique called roasting.

Titular: Newmont rejects $18bn hostile approach by rival Barrick
Subtitular: Miner insists $10bn plan to take over Goldcorp is better for shareholders
Texto: Newmont Mining has rebuffed an $18bn hostile takeover offer from rival Barrick Gold that would have created the world’s largest gold miner, instead proposing a plan to combine the two producers’ lucrative Nevada operations in a joint venture.Gary Goldberg, Newmont’s chief executive, said a previously agreed $10bn takeover of Canada’s Goldcorp was the best deal for shareholders as he dismissed Barrick’s offer as “egocentric”.“The combination with Goldcorp is significantly more accretive to Newmont’s shareholders on all relevant metrics compared with Barrick’s proposal,” Mr Goldberg said.A merger of Barrick and Newmont would create a gold-mining giant with annual production of more than 10m ounces. However, Barrick has not offered a premium, telling shareholders they would benefit from the value created by merging the two companies.A deal will ultimately be decided by a small group of shareholders who own both companies. Newmont’s Mr Goldberg and Tom Palmer — who will take over from Mr Goldberg later this year — will meet shareholders this week, including BlackRock, the largest shareholder in Newmont.The investors will debate whether the two companies’ operations in Nevada are best combined either via a joint venture or a takeover by Barrick. Barrick has significant reserves in Nevada, while Newmont also has large processing facilities in the US state.Under Newmont’s proposal Barrick would have a 55 per cent economic interest in the Nevada venture and Newmont 45 per cent — a split that would also be reflected in their respective voting rights.“Newmont has consistently expressed to Barrick that we are open to a joint venture for our operations in Nevada,” said Mr Goldberg. “This proposal would enable both companies’ shareholders to realise the available synergies while avoiding the significant risks and complexities associated with Barrick’s unsolicited proposal.”But Mark Bristow, Barrick’s chief executive, said the joint venture proposal reinforced the frustration Barrick had experienced in its efforts to unlock the value in the two companies’ assets in Nevada.“Newmont’s latest proposal is essentially based on the stale and convoluted process that foundered previously. As usual, it comes with unrealistic preconditions including swapping the chairmanship and the leadership of the JV. Experience has shown us that JVs only work well when the majority owner is also the operator,” he said.Mr Goldberg raised doubts over the ability of Mr Bristow to run a global company and realise the promised $750m of annual cost savings and synergies.“Prior to assuming his new role at Barrick, Mark managed only five assets on one continent — he has never managed a global portfolio like Barrick’s,” Mr Goldberg said.A combination of Barrick and Newmont would create a company with operations on five continents in 18 different countries.“The risks are too huge: the integration risks, the ESG [environmental, social and governance] risks of having Barrick running both companies are huge,” Mr Palme told the Financial Times.Mr Bristow was appointed chief executive of Barrick this year following the takeover of Randgold Resources, the London-listed gold producer he co-founded.Mr Goldberg said that John Thornton, Barrick’s executive chairman and a former Goldman Sachs banker, was the “ultimate decision maker” in the company.In a sign of the growing hostilities between the two companies, Newmont released private communications between Mr Bristow and Ian Telfer, Goldcorp chairman, in which Mr Bristow praised Goldcorp’s “strong portfolio” of assets in “world-class districts”.Mr Bristow has criticised Newmont’s plan to buy Goldcorp’s “second-tier assets” as “desperate and bizarre”.

Titular: Barrick Gold chief sets sights on conquering mining world
Subtitular: Game hunter Mark Bristow aims to expand empire beyond Africa with Newmont bid
Texto: Mark Bristow, the straight-talking chief executive of Barrick Gold, is a life-long adventurer and adrenalin junkie. He has driven motorcycles across Africa for charity, run marathons, hunted big game and enjoys flying. With characteristic bluntness, he has said that any gold miner “needs to have balls”.After the Barrick-Randgold merger was announced last year, pictures soon emerged of Mr Bristow standing proudly behind slain animals with a gun.“I’m a passionate African. I love the wildlife. I’ve spent my whole life involved in conservation,” he said. “I don’t think it’s got anything to do with my ability to run a world-class gold business.”A long-time critic of the gold industry’s wasteful mergers, he has also taken pot shots at investment bankers, accusing them of “mixing ice cream and cow shit” in order to pocket big advisory fees.Over the past five years his quarterly briefings to investors in London have nearly always been accompanied by a critique of the industry, which he said had been better at destroying than creating value for investors.Now, he has to convince investors that his $18bn hostile bid for rival Newmont Mining this week is different and will create value for shareholders rather than end up joining a long list of value-destructive mining mergers.Newmont’s chief executive Gary Goldberg said Mr Bristow was pursuing the same “hostile and value destructive tactics” as John Thornton, the former Goldman Sachs banker who chairs Barrick.But Mr Bristow, who took Barrick’s helm in January following the takeover of Randgold Resources, the London-listed gold miner he founded — insists the deal will deliver real returns.What I do is I get into the weeds. We run our business. We are businessmen. We are not corporate people that have processesHe accuses Newmont of running its business remotely from head-office, ticking corporate boxes rather than letting local managers run the mines.“Newmont is a big Rio Tinto-style business that doesn’t get down into the weeds, it has a process,” Mr Bristow said. “Whereas what I do is I get into the weeds. We run our business. We are businessmen. We are not corporate people that have processes.”If his tilt is successful, it would mark a remarkable ascent to the top of the gold-mining world for Mr Bristow, who was born as one of five children in Estcourt, a small farming town north of Durban in South Africa.Mr Bristow has won respect for operating in difficult countries in Africa and turning Randgold Resources into the best performing stock in London this century, with total returns of more than 7,000 per cent before its takeover.If the bid for Newmont is successful, he will be in charge of a huge company with operations from Latin America to Papua New Guinea.Leaving school at 18, he did active service in the South African army in what is now Namibia and Angola. He then studied geology at the University of Natal, going on to do a Masters and PhD thesis on platinum in the Bushveld Complex.Mr Bristow joined Rand Mines in 1981 and then became head of exploration at Randgold & Exploration, which was spun out of the company to manage its South African gold mines. In 1995 he decided to branch out on his own, raising money to buy a mine in Mali from BHP Billiton and listing Randgold Resources in London two years later.Mr Bristow’s key idea was to leave South Africa and explore for gold in French-speaking west Africa, which had been overlooked by the anglophone mining industry during the cold war.“Mark had the vision to form an African exploration company,” said David Reading, a geologist who followed Mark from Rand Mines to Randgold. “Mark was very passionate about strategy and delivery of strategic objectives. He had that famous saying that ‘if you don’t know where you want to go, any road will take you’. You have to have strategy in a company and a direction.”After an early setback in Mali, Randgold went on to build five mines in west Africa, shunning mergers and acquisitions after a failed bid for AngloGold Ashanti in 2003.“If you mix cow shit and ice cream, you never, never improve the taste of the cow shit,” Mr Bristow told journalists in January.“The principle behind that is stick to ice cream. It’s better. That’s what Randgold did. We tried very hard to be an ice cream company.”A workaholic who maintains a punishing travel schedule from his home in Mauritius, Mr Bristow has already instituted the “Randgold culture” at Barrick, cutting one entire floor of the head office in Toronto.Still, some have doubted that Mr Bristow has what it takes to play in the big league and run a complex global mining company that will employ tens of thousands of people and contractors.Mr Bristow has also experienced health problems. He had open-heart surgery in 2017 after a doctor spotted a problem during a routine medical to renew his pilot’s licence.“I was anxious about the whole thing,” Mr Bristow said last year. “The operation was tough. 11 hours. But I was walking on day two.”With his health restored and having largely conquered Africa, the question for investors is whether he can conquer the rest of the world by creating the most powerful force in the global mining industry. It is a bold move from an adventurer whose risk-taking has paid off in the past.

Titular: Barrick chief Bristow rules out higher offer for Newmont
Subtitular: Boss of gold miner looks to convince investors of case for acquisition
Texto: Barrick Gold’s boss Mark Bristow has ruled out increasing his offer for arch rival Newmont Mining.Mr Bristow told the Financial Times the $18bn nil-premium, all-stock offer for Newmont was “logical” and would combine multiple world-class gold mines into one company.Asked if Barrick would increase its offer for Newmont, Mr Bristow said “no”.“What’s better than five world class assets? Eight,” Mr Bristow said. “We can demonstrate that it’s so logical . . . [Synergies] are about whether you put two things together is better or worse? And it’s far better.”Mr Bristow has to convince a small group of investors who have shareholdings in both companies that the deal makes more sense than Newmont’s planned $10bn acquisition of Vancouver-based Goldcorp, which was announced in January.BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, has a 14.9 per cent stake in Newmont and a 6 per cent stake in Barrick.Earlier this week Mr Bristow spent an hour with Evy Hambro, the head of Blackrock’s influential mining fund, discussing the merits of his offer, according to a person familiar with the meeting.“I am working so hard to get the shareholders to decide. Let the shareholders decide and my proposal gives them a better option than what the new team in Newmont says,” Mr Bristow said. “This proposal will fly or die on the merits, it has to,” he added.Combining Barrick and Newmont would create a company with more than 10m ounces of annual production, far surpassing any of its rivals, with revenues of $15.6bn and underlying earnings of $7bn.On Thursday Barrick gave more details of the benefits of the deal with Newmont.In an updated investor presentation, Barrick provided a detailed breakdown of $500m of annual synergies its said could be unlocked by combining their respective operations in the US state.

Titular: Barrick fires further salvo at Newmont
Texto: Barrick Gold has fired a further salvo at arch rival Newmont Mining as it seeks to persuade shareholders to back its $18bn hostile offer.In an updated investor presentation, Barrick rubbished the idea of a joint venture in Nevada and provided a detailed breakdown of $500m of annual synergies its said could be unlocked by combining their respective operations in the US state.It also took aim at Newmont’s performance and criticised its chief executive Gary Goldberg for not prioritising “the realisation of Nevada’s full potential.”“Newmont’s CEO admitted he hasn’t reviewed the opportunity since 2014, and only then a high level review for a couple of days,” the presentation said.It continued: “Nevada JV is not the right path forward. [It] would not enable full realisation of benefits due to duplicate administration, conflicting priorities and cumbersome governance.”Barrick launched its $18bn nil-premium offer for Newmont on Monday, unleashing a bitter war of words between two companies.Mr Goldberg has questioned whether his opposite number at Barrick, Mark Bristow, has the experience to run a global company.Mr Bristow, meanwhile, has slammed Newmont’s plan to buy miner Goldcorp, calling the $10bn acquisition “desperate and bizarre”.In Thursday’s presentation Barrick said it had outperformed Newmont by 20 per cent since its $6bn acquisition of Randgold Resources was announced in September.Mr Bristow was CEO of Randgold, which he helped build into London’s biggest gold before its sale to Barrick.However, some analysts and investors are concerned about his ability to take on another big deal while he is still trying to knit together Barrick and Randgold.Combining Barrick and Newmont would create a company with more than 10m ounces of annual production, far surpassing any of its rivals, with revenues of $15.6bn and underlying earnings of $7bn.“In our view both Newmont and Barrick management team are capable,” said analysts at Credit Suisse in a report. “However, we note that Barrick’s bid for Newmont suggests that, if successful, it would have to simultaneously integrate Randgold and Newmont, which could be a tough task for even experienced senior executives”.Ultimately, the success of Barrick’s hostile bid will boil down to whether shareholders are prepared to accept Barrick’s nil-premium offer and believe Mr Bristow can deliver the promised synergies. So far, Mr Bristow has not been drawn on whether he will increase his offer.Newmont’s biggest shareholder is BlackRock, which owns 14.9 per cent of the company. The asset manager also has a 6.1 per cent stake in Barrick.In an interview with the Financial Times, Flossbach von Storch, the German asset manager that is a top-five investor in both gold miners, said the idea of combining the two companies was attractive if they could be integrated seamlessly.

Titular: Key shareholder voices support for Barrick-Newmont deal
Subtitular: Investors clash on merits of $18bn merger of gold miners
Texto: The biggest active investor in Barrick Gold and Newmont Mining has thrown its support behind the $18bn merger of the two long-term rivals but only if they can come to an amicable agreement.Flossbach von Storch, the German asset manager that is a top-five investor in both gold miners with holdings worth more than $1bn, said the idea of combining the best assets in the industry was attractive if they could be integrated seamlessly.“We like the approach and the optionality that comes with the Barrick merger proposal but — and this is the important thing — it has to be seamless and not too hostile,” said Simon Jäger, portfolio manager at Flossbach von Storch. “Both parties need to want this deal.”Toronto-based Barrick on Monday stunned the gold industry when it unveiled a hostile $18bn bid for its closest rival Newmont, just over a month after it acquired London-listed rival Randgold. Barrick’s chief executive Mark Bristow has claimed he could generate annual pre-tax synergies from the deal of $750m.One leading gold investor lobbying against the deal said the promised synergies were “fiction” and questioned Mr Bristow’s ability to deliver them.New York-based Coast Capital has written to shareholders in Newmont Mining urging them to oppose Barrick Gold’s bid, which it attacked as “poorly conceived and extraordinarily aggressive”.Shareholders’ Gold Council has not commented on the deal.“[The] synergies claimed by Bristow are taken as fact by investors and observers — but given the fact that most mergers fail to realise any synergies, we are well advised to have very tempered expectations,” according to a copy of the letter. “Indeed, if Barrick has 100 per cent confidence in these claimed synergies, why not pay 50 per cent of them at least to Newmont to secure the deal?”Coast Capital said Mr Bristow, who was previously chief executive of Africa-focused gold miner Randgold Resources, does not have a record of managing a company of this size with far-flung operations.In addition, photos of Mr Bristow hunting big game in Africa would not go down well with investors in North America, Coast Capital said.“I would rather not spend time in a room with someone who thinks that killing defenceless animals is what one should do with one’s life,” James Rasteh, partner at Coast Capital, said.The success of Barrick’s bid will be determined by a small group of investors who own shares in both companies. These include Flossbach von Storch and BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager.They must decide whether the deal makes more sense than Newmont’s planned $10bn acquisition of Vancouver-based Goldcorp, which was announced last month.In an aggressive move last week Barrick bought 1,000 shares of Newmont and proposed a motion to reduce the percentage required to call a shareholder vote to 15 per cent of shareholders from 25 per cent.Newmont’s biggest shareholder is BlackRock, which owns 14.9 per cent of the company. The asset manager also has a 6.1 per cent stake in Barrick.While most of the shares are owned by BlackRock’s iShares exchange traded funds business, a portion are held by the influential London-based BlackRock World Mining Trust, which is managed by Evy Hambro and Olivia Markham.BlackRock is also a large shareholder in Goldcorp, with a 7.2 per cent stake. If a deal is called off, shares in Goldcorp are likely to fall sharply.New York-based Van Eck Associates is the largest shareholder in Barrick and the third-largest shareholder of Newmont. Joe Foster, a gold fund manager at Van Eck, said he still had not formed a final opinion on the deal.

Titular: Barrick Gold launches $18bn hostile offer for Newmont
Subtitular: All-share deal for US rival would create gold mining behemoth
Texto: Barrick Gold has launched a hostile $18bn all-stock offer for its closest rival Newmont Mining, unleashing a bitter war of words between two companies whose combination would create the world’s biggest gold producer. Toronto-listed Barrick said a nil-premium merger would offer greater benefits to shareholders than Newmont’s planned $10bn acquisition of Canadian miner Goldcorp, which it attacked as “desperate and bizarre”.Newmont hit back, defending its Goldcorp deal and saying Barrick had an “ineffective operating mode” and a “poor track record” on delivering shareholder returns. The US company said significant cost savings could be more effectively realised through a joint venture in Nevada, where both companies have significant gold deposits. Barrick’s offer for Newmont is the latest attempt to combine two fierce rivals that have flirted with a merger in the past. A potential tie-up collapsed at the last minute in 2014 because of personality clashes between senior executives. Barrick is led by chief executive Mark Bristow, a South African miner fond of big game hunting, and executive chairman John Thornton, an urbane former Goldman Sachs banker. Paying a 17 premium for Goldcorp with its second-tier assets and no synergies followed by the departure of the Newmont CEO strikes me as both desperate and bizarreThey are pitted against Newmont chief executive Gary Goldberg, a former Rio Tinto executive who is set to retire this year, and chair Noreen Doyle, also a former banker.The offer for Newmont is an extraordinarily bold gambit by Barrick, which is still digesting its $6bn purchase of Randgold Resources, the London-listed gold miner co-founded by Mr Bristow.The deal would create a $40bn company with more than 10m ounces of annual production, far surpassing any of its rivals, with revenues of $15.6bn and underlying earnings of $7bn. Barrick estimates there would be annual pre-tax synergies of $750m from the deal with Newmont in the first five years, primarily by combing their respective gold mines in Nevada. Further costs savings would be generated by closing Newmont’s head office in Denver and cutting staff, Mr Bristow said. Mines would be run by local managers, he said.“In this modern world — you don’t need a huge head office,” said Mr Bristow.In contrast, Newmont’s deal with Goldcorp will generate just $165m of annual synergies.“Paying a 17 premium for Goldcorp with its second-tier assets and no synergies followed by the departure of the Newmont CEO strikes me as both desperate and bizarre,” Mr Bristow said.Newmont shareholders will now have to decide whether to choose Barrick’s nil-premium offer or push ahead and vote in favour of the Goldcorp deal. Newmont has been one of the best-performing gold miners over the past decade and is the only gold miner in the S&P 500. “Where would you put your retirement money? Who would you want to invest in? We have a proven record of running a global mining company,” said Mr Goldberg. “Mark has done a great job of running an African-region business with mines all close to each other. It’s a different business running a global business.”Under the offer, Newmont shareholders would receive 2.5694 Barrick shares, giving them 44.1 per cent of the combined company. Barrick said the deal was conditional on Newmont scrapping its planned all-stock acquisition of Goldcorp, which has received a lukewarm response from investors.That takeover is due to close in the second quarter of 2019 after a shareholder vote and Goldcorp is entitled to a $650m fee if Newmont abandons the takeover.In an interview with the Financial Times, Mr Goldberg said he was “perplexed” by the offer and the two companies should instead work on a joint venture in Nevada. “You don’t need to go through all this hoopla they’re going through currently to extract that value,” he said.While Barrick has the majority of the high-grade gold reserves and resources in Nevada, Newmont has most of the processing plant capacity and infrastructure.Shares in Barrick fell 1 per cent to C$16.98, while Newmont dropped by 0.3 per cent to $36. Goldcorp was down 0.3 per cent to C$14.56. James Milligan, analyst at Olivetree Financial, said the success of the deal would depend on whether shareholders would back Mr Bristow and believe in his record of creating shareholder value while at Randgold.“We believe the gravitas of Mark Bristow and history of returning capital to shareholders may well enable Barrick to successfully negotiate a hostile acquisition of Newmont,” he said.

Titular: Newmont chief ready to discuss Nevada potential with Barrick Gold
Subtitular: Gary Goldberg speaks after hostile all-share bid from Canadian rival
Texto: Gary Goldberg, the chief executive of Newmont Mining, said he is willing to sit down with Barrick Gold’s Mark Bristow to discuss a combination of their extensive gold mines in the US state of Nevada.Speaking minutes after the Canadian gold miner launched an $18bn hostile all-share bid for Newmont, Mr Goldberg said he was “perplexed” by the offer and the two companies should instead work on a joint venture in Nevada.Mr Goldberg said Barrick did not need to go through all the “hoopla” of making another big acquisition just months after it absorbed Randgold Resources, London’s biggest gold company.“A JV in Nevada makes a lot of sense,” Mr Goldberg told the Financial Times. “It’s what I talked to him [Mr Bristow] last about on December 20 and he seemed amenable to it. You don’t need to go through all this hoopla they’re going through currently to extract that value.”In a separate interview Mr Bristow claimed that Barrick had tried to engage Newmont in talks over a joint venture in Nevada several times in the past but had received a lukewarm response. He claimed that Mr Goldberg was unaware of the synergies of combining their extensive gold assets in the state.Barrick claims it could generate more than $1bn of synergies through a combination with Newmont.“We’re just moving dirt past each other,” Mr Bristow said about their operations in Nevada.

Titular: Barrick calls for Newmont shareholder proposal after bid consideration
Texto: Newmont Mining said on Monday rival Barrick would propose making it easier for investors to call a shareholder meeting, following its consideration of a hostile bid for the gold miner. The US miner said Barrick, which owns a small stake in Newmont, intended to propose to shareholders that the threshold to requisition a meeting be lowered to 15 per cent from 25 per cent. That comes after Barrick last week reviewed making a nil-premium all-share approach for Newmont, a $19bn deal that would create the world’s largest gold miner. “Newmont does not intend to speculate about Barrick’s motivations or intentions and reserves all rights with respect to the shareholder proposals,” Newmont said.However, analysts said the move could allow Blackrock, which owns 14.9 per cent of Newmont, to emerge as kingmaker in a deal. The fund manager also owns 4.3 per cent of Barrick.Newmont said its proposed merger with gold miner Goldcorp represented the best value for shareholders. The deal, which is set to complete in the second quarter, will create a gold miner with assets on four continents and generate benefits of around $165m a year, it said. But Barrick could scupper that deal if it makes its own approach. Both Barrick and Newmont have large gold operations in Nevada, and Barrick’s chief executive Mark Bristow has said there are opportunities to work together in the state. Newmont and Barrick previously considered a merger in 2014 but the deal was scotched by Barrick’s executive chairman John Thornton, a former Goldman Sachs banker. Barrick owns 1,000 shares in Newmont, out of a total of 535m outstanding shares in the company.

Titular: Barrick/Newmont: pan it
Subtitular: After past acquisitions that were less than glorious, the latest $19bn deal seems hubristic
Texto: People pay a premium for gold, but producers of the shiny stuff would rather not. Look at the two largest gold mining deals in the past six months. Barrick Gold acquired the UK’s Randgold for no premium. Last month Newmont Mining bid for Canada’s Goldcorp on a low-ish 17 per cent premium. Reports that Barrick may buy Newmont Mining, with no premium, continue the trend. Miners probably fear their shareholders.For good reason. As an example, until Randgold, Barrick had hardly covered itself in glory on past purchases. One in particular, its 2011 $7.6bn purchase of copper miner Equinox, rankled. Barrick’s debt jumped. Servicing it became harder as gold prices later fell. The nil premium $6bn takeover for Randgold, completed in January, made more sense given that it brought in well-regarded chief executive Mark Bristow. Randgold shareholders could benefit from a larger gold portfolio.However, tacking another nearly $19bn deal for US-listed Newmont appears hubristic. Put the two together and the new company easily tops the gold production table with well over 10m ounces a year, depending on any asset sales later. Even so, Barrick must have had potentially furious shareholders in mind. Its press release specifically mentions an all-share, nil premium deal.On those terms, and putting aside any regulatory objections, the combination would make financial sense, adding to earnings per share. Neither side holds much debt, so that is not a concern. Even if Newmont dropped the Goldcorp deal, adding a $650m break fee would not move that needle much. At the same time Barrick and Newmont have contiguous gold assets in Nevada, so there are potential cost savings there.However, Newmont shareholders might rightly ask why, if unappreciated Goldcorp deserved even a modest premium, their own company should receive none. That question should stop a Barrick-Newmont deal.Lex publishes two popular newsletters for premium subscribers. Wednesday: Lex Letter From London, New York or San Francisco. Fridays: Best of Lex, a weekly round-up. Please sign up at ft.com/newsletters.

Titular: Barrick Gold ‘reviewed opportunity’ to merge with rival Newmont
Subtitular: Deal would create world’s largest gold mining company
Texto: Barrick Gold confirmed it had “reviewed the opportunity” to merge with rival Newmont Mining, in a $19bn deal that would create the world’s largest gold mining company.The Canadian miner, which only completed its acquisition of London-listed Randgold Resources last month, said it had looked at a nil-premium share transaction to merge with Colorado-based Newmont. It said no decision had been taken on a deal.If Barrick were to proceed it would mark a stunning offensive by Barrick’s chief Mark Bristow, the ambitious South African who was chief executive of Randgold, and executive chairman John Thornton, a former Goldman Sachs banker.It comes as gold prices hit their highest level in 10 months this week, a rally that has renewed interest in the gold sector following years of lacklustre returns and investor apathy.“It’s an enormous deal,” said Robert Gill, a fund manager a Lincluden Investment Management in Canada. “There’s an argument that can be made that for the gold sector to come back into favour, capital will move first to the largest players so there’s an incentive to be a large player.”The move threatens to thwart Newmont’s $10bn acquisition of Canadian miner Goldcorp, which it announced in January. The deal, which still needs to be voted on by shareholders, would create a larger gold miner than Barrick with production of 6m-7m ounces a year.If the Barrick-Newmont deal were to go ahead then Barrick would have to pay a break-up fee of $650m to Goldcorp. The size of the deal would also be closely scrutinised by competition authorities.Barrick is set to produce between 5.1m and 5.6m ounces of gold this year, while Newmont said this week it was targeting 5.2m ounces of gold production.Barrick’s statement on Friday followed media reports that the company was considering a takeover of Newmont, to be followed by the sale of its Australian mines to gold miner Newcrest.Newmont did not respond to questions on the announcement. Newcrest declined to comment.“Barrick Gold today confirmed that the company has reviewed the opportunity to merge with Newmont Mining Corporation in an all-share nil premium transaction,” Barrick said. “No decision has been taken at this time.”Barrick shares were down about 1 per cent at midday in New York while Newmont was up 5 per cent.Newmont’s proposed $10bn acquisition of Goldcorp drew a lukewarm response from analysts and investors when it was announced last month. Investors baulked at the 17 per cent premium Newmont had offered as well as the projected $100m of annual cost savings.Colorado-based Newmont, which was founded by promoter Colonel William Boyce Thompson in 1916, has no gold mines in Canada while Goldcorp has no mines in the US.Barrick and Newmont, however, both have large operations in Nevada, increasing the opportunities for cost savings and synergies. On February 13 Mr Bristow said there were “combination opportunities with other operators in the area”.There was an opportunity to combine their processing capacity in Nevada, Mr Bristow said. Bankers said there could be $1bn of synergies in Nevada if the two companies combined operations.“The Achilles heel of Nevada is the processing facilities,” he told the Financial Times.Newmont currently owns 25 per cent of Barrick’s Turquoise Ridge underground mine in Nevada. Turquoise Ridge has the highest grades of gold in the industry, according to Barrick.Barrick and Newmont discussed a merger in 2014 but talks were ended by Mr Thornton, according to Vincent Calarco, who was chairman of Newmont at the time. Mr Calarco said that efforts to find a consensus were “rejected out of hand repeatedly”.Additional reporting by Arash Massoudi in London

Titular: Newmont’s incoming CEO defends $10bn Goldcorp deal
Texto: The incoming chief executive of the world’s largest gold miner says he’s confident Newmont Mining will be able to maintain profitable gold production at 6m to 7m ounces a year for “a couple of decades” following its $10bn acquisition of Goldcorp.Tom Palmer, who is set to replace Gary Goldberg as Newmont chief executive later this year following the closure of the deal, said there was an opportunity to find more gold at Goldcorp’s mines in Mexico, Argentina and Canada.“We see a real value proposition in this acquisition in bringing Newmont’s exploration expertise to bear on these assets,” Mr Palmer told the Financial Times. “We see real opportunity to leverage our technology and expertise in that space.”Shares in Colorado-based Newmont have fallen 9 per cent since it announced the deal to acquire Vancouver-based Goldcorp last Monday.Mr Palmer, who previously worked at Rio Tinto, said Newmont had sent its “best and brightest” to do due diligence on Goldcorp’s assets.Mr Palmer pointed to the potential for adding gold at Goldcorp’s remote Cerro Negro mine in Argentina as well as its Penasquito mine in northern Mexico.Goldcorp bought Cerro Negro for $3.6bn in 2010 but had to write down the project by $2.3bn in 2015. The mine is located 600m above sea level in southern Argentina.“When we look at Cerro Negro we see the opportunity to bring some of Newmont’s operational expertise to bear, we are quite excited about the exploration around that region,” he said.In Canada, Goldcorp’s Musselwhite mine below Opapimiskan Lake also has potential, Mr Palmer said. The Musselwhite mine includes some 17,500 hectares of mine claims and leases in the North Caribou Greenstone belt, according to Goldcorp.Mr Palmer, currently chief operating officer at Newmont, was recruited by Mr Goldberg to join Newmont in November 2014. They first met when they both worked for Rio Tinto.Still, Mr Palmer said the miner would not chase growth “for growth’s sake”.He added: “We’re not chasing volume.”

Titular: Newmont Mining shares down again in wake of Goldcorp takeover plan
Texto: Shares in Newmont Mining fell again on Tuesday as its $10bn takeover of Canadian rival Goldcorp drew lukewarm response from analysts and investors.The New York-listed group announced plans to buy Goldcorp on Monday, a deal it said would create the world’s biggest gold producer with the biggest reserve and resource base in the industry. It will also take Newmont into new geographies such as Canada and Chile.“This is not a deal we have to do. This is a deal we want to do,” said Newmont chief executive Gary Goldberg.However, investors baulked at the 17 per cent premium Newmont said it would pay for its struggling rival and also the surprise news that Mr Goldberg would retire by the end of the year.All of that triggered a sharp fall in its share price, which continued on Tuesday. Newmont was down 2.6 per cent at $30.94, giving the company a market value of $16.4bn“While this transaction will give Newmont some growth potential and operational upside, we do not see the justification for Newmont to pay a significant (17 per cent) premium,” said Jefferies analyst Christopher LaFemina.The premium paid by Newmont is in stark contrast to the deal that saw Barrick Gold take control of London’s Randgold Resources. That was structured as a nil-premium merger.Others expressed disappointment at the projected $100m of annual cost savings from the Newmont-Goldcorp deal.“Newmont has nothing in Canada. Goldcorp don’t have anything in the US. The company came out and said they can save $100mln a year. Chopping out HQ costs will probably go some way to getting to that but from an asset and jurisdictional perspective, I don’t see the perfect fit,” said Numis Securities.

Titular: Investors hit out at payout due Goldcorp chief from Newmont deal
Subtitular: Shareholders’ Gold Council says David Garofalo ‘massively overpaid’ since appointment
Texto: A group of gold investors including New York hedge fund Paulson & Co has slammed Newmont’s planned $10bn acquisition of rival Goldcorp and the estimated $8m reward due its chief executive from the deal.The 16-member Shareholders’ Gold Council, which was formed last year to promote the interests of gold investors, said Goldcorp’s CEO, David Garofalo, had been “massively overpaid” since his appointment in 2016 and now stood to garner $8m due to change of control provisions in his contract.Shares in Vancouver-based Goldcorp have fallen by 26 per cent under Mr Garofalo, while he was paid over C$16m in aggregate compensation in 2016 and 2017, the group said. Newmont’s proposal on Monday will see it offer 0.3280 of its own shares for each Goldcorp share, plus 2 cents in cash, an 18 per cent premium to Friday’s closing price.“While Mr Garofalo has been massively overpaid, stockholders have lost over C$3.7bn since his appointment, and Goldcorp now wants to sell itself at only a slight premium to its 1,3,5,7 and 10-year low in share price,” the Shareholders’ Gold Council said.“The merger with Newmont is only a victory for shareholders in as much as it eliminates another gold company with executive incentives that are grossly misaligned with those of shareholders,” it added.Mr Garofalo said on Monday that he wasn’t clear yet whether he would stay on at the combined company following the deal.Newmont’s chief executive Gary Goldberg said he would remain in his position to close the acquisition after which the company’s chief operating officer Tom Palmer will take over.Newmont’s shares fell by 9 per cent following news of the deal on Monday to close at $31.78 on the New York Stock Exchange, while Goldcorp’s rose by 8 per cent to close at C$13.83 in Toronto.

Titular: Gold miners prepare to strike deals
Subtitular: Newmont’s tie-up with Goldcorp looks set to boost further M&A in fragmented sector
Texto: Who is next? That is the question investors are asking after Newmont Mining made a $10bn swoop for Canada’s Goldcorp, a deal that will create the world’s leading gold producer.Following Barrick Gold’s $6bn takeover of Randgold Resources last September, analysts now expect a flurry of dealmaking as the industry seeks to improve its performance and boost shareholder returns.“Now you’ve got these two large players with impressive production and renewed vigour, you’re going to see a number of the mid-tier players have to do something or want to do something,” said Robert Gill, a portfolio manager at Lincluden Investment Management in Canada.Others agree.
