He said Mr Humala enjoys good relations with local business groups and would implement an orthodox fiscal policy.“If anyone is frightened, they should knock on the door and talk to the candidate,” the former central bank director told the FT.Mr Humala has unsettled investors by calling for the nationalisation of “strategic sectors” of the economy such as mining, hydrocarbons and utilities.At a campaign rally in La Victoria, a poor area of Lima, on Wednesday night, Mr Humala told a crowd of 20,000 that “foreign companies continue to enter our country and destroy our industries” and pledged to “rescind contracts that are against the national interest”.Mr García said the emphasis would be on promoting local Peruvian investment in industry rather than creating new state companies. “Peru’s government often operates as though its main priority is to defend the interests of private companies,” he said. “We have to nationalise the state, so it defends national interests.”Under Alejandro Toledo, the current president, Peru has been one of the most open economies in the region. Gross domestic product grew 6.7 per cent last year and the economy has expanded for 55 consecutive months.Mr Jiménez defended his party’s proposed tax increases, which would raise the burden from 13.8 per cent to 18 per cent of gross domestic product. “Peru has one of the lowest tax rates in the world,” he said.Over three years a Humala government would double infrastructure spending, from 2.5 to 5 per cent of GDP, but Mr Jiménez said the deficit would be kept below one per cent of GDP.The Humala aide said the government would maintain inflation at its current low level, with prices targeted to rise no more than 2.5 per cent a year.

Titular: Gold Fields playing catalyst to precious metals fusion
Texto: The prospect of a merger between UK-listed Lonmin and Gold Fields of South Africa is likely to yield mixed opinions among investors and analysts in the precious metals mining sector.For the last few years, the trend in the mining sector has been for gold and platinum companies to keep their distance.Investors like to buy a stock that gives them direct exposure to gold or platinum prices and these companies’ shares command a premium over those of diversified mining companies such as Rio Tinto or BHP Billiton.Brad Mills, Lonmin’s chief executive who has a background in base metals, tried to move into other types of mining after he was appointed in 2004 but was given a stern rebuke from shareholders who wanted him to stick with platinum.But the gold and platinum industries have been intertwined before. Lonmin rose from the ashes of Tiny Rowland’s Lonrho empire, which included gold mining interests in Ghana.Until 2004, Lonmin owned a sizeable stake in Ashanti Goldfields of Ghana.Lonmin sold this stake to Anglo Gold of South Africa as part of its takeover of the Ghanaian group. And Gold Fields has shown interest in the platinum market over the last few years. In 2003, it bought into a platinum exploration project in Finland called Arctic Platinum.Lonmin is the world’s third-largest producer of platinum after South Africa’s Anglo Platinum and Impala Platinum.Gold Fields, meanwhile, is the fourth-largest gold producer after Barrick of Canada, Newmont of the US and AngloGold Ashanti.Gold Fields and Lonmin have a significant presence in South Africa. Until 2001, Gold Fields produced all of its gold from South African mines. It has since diversified into Australia and Ghana and recently made an offer for Bolivar Gold, a Venezuelan gold miner, for $360m (£207m).All of Lonmin’s mines are in South Africa, the source of more than three-quarters of the world’s supply of platinum. The mines are located in the Bushveld region, home to a large and unique deposit of rich platinum ore.The Bushveld has been thoroughly explored and new opportunities are thin on the ground, however, so Lonmin is funding exploration elsewhere.Although the gold price has performed well in the last few months, breaking through the psychological barrier of $500 an ounce, South African gold companies have seen their profit hit by rising costs and declining production.It is not surprising that Gold Fields has been looking at wider options. The platinum price has also had a phenomenal run, supported by strong demand from jewellery customers and the automotive industry, where the metal is used in catalytic converters.Gold Fields has so far not taken part in the recent wave of consolidation in the gold industry.In October 2004, Harmony Gold of South Africa made an audacious hostile bid for its larger rival and won the support of Norilsk Nickel of Russia, Gold Fields’ largest shareholder.But Gold Fields successfully fought off the bid.While it is not yet clear whether the talks between Lonmin and Gold Fields will result in a deal, it is certain that the Russian group will have a large role to play.

Titular: Newmont and Jakarta settle pollution dispute
Texto: Newmont, the world’s largest gold producer, signed a deal with the Indonesian government on Thursday in which the company would pay $30m over the next 10 years to partially resolve a bitter 18-month-old environmental dispute.The “goodwill agreement” is meant to bring an end to a $135m civil suit filed by Jakarta over alleged pollution at Newmont’s now-shut Minahasa Raya mine in North Sulawesi.The Denver-based miner and a senior executive still face criminal charges in a trial now underway that is expected to drag on until June or July.Under the terms of the agreement signed on Thursday, Newmont will pay the equivalent of $3m a year to fund a new foundation to oversee community development projects around the Minahasa mine site. The money will also go to funding a six-person scientific panel that will monitor both the environment and the health of villagers around the mine site.But Wayne Murdy, Newmont’s chairman and chief executive, said the signing of the agreement on Thursday, was a “positive step” for the company.“It’s time that this be over,” he said. “We have felt very strongly about the science here. The fact that we are willing to subject ourselves to 10 years of scrutiny whereas the closure plan [for the mine, which was shut in August 2004] called for two [means] we’re just trying to display that we feel absolutely confident about the science.”The agreement signed on Thursday is likely to be seen as a significant win for President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono and his efforts to bring foreign investment back to south-east Asia’s largest economy. According to data released on Wednesday, Indonesia’s GDP grew by an annualised 4.9 per cent - its slowest growth in six quarters - in the final three months of 2005.The deal is also expected to ease some of the pressure that US-based Newmont has felt over its environmental practices as part of a mounting global campaign against the gold industry.The agreement calls for Jakarta to abandon efforts to revive the $135m civil suit it filed against Newmont last year and withdraw an appeal to Indonesia’s Supreme Court against a lower-court ruling that threw out the case.Mr Murdy said on Thursday that Newmont remained “very confident” that it would prevail in the ongoing criminal trial.According to people close to both sides, the agreement signed on Thursday contains wording that would help partially exonerate Newmont by pointing to conflicting evidence over whether any arsenic, mercury or other heavy-metal pollution occurred near the Minahasa Raya mine.The agreement would not exonerate the mining company wholly, and the company is understood to have sought a stronger wording.However, the formation of the scientific team, a senior Newmont official said, would provide a “strong scientific underpinning that will confirm that there is no pollution”.Mahendra Siregar, spokesman for Indonesia’s chief economics minister, said the government’s position remainted that there had been pollution at Newmont’s operations. But he said Jakarta had decided to set aside the issue. “We don’t want to pursue this in court. We don’t think that is the right way.”Mr Yudhoyono’s government has been trying to re-energise a stalled economic reform programme. The government is due on Thursday to brief key donors on a new investment package that would involve the revamping of a controversial draft tax law and the introduction of new investment and labour laws.Jakarta is also understood to be a step closer to resolving a long-running dispute with ExxonMobil over control of a $2bn oilfield in Java.

Titular: Indonesia raises hopes for outside investors
Texto: Indonesia has never been an easy place to do business and, in recent years, high-profile disputes between Jakarta and foreign investors such as ExxonMobil, Cemex and Newmont have stood as stark evidence of that.The result, in a world where investors are able to shift foreign capital across borders quickly, is easy to identify. Eight years on, Indonesia’s economy continues to struggle to recover from the Asian financial crisis and rid itself of the structural legacies of 32 years of crony capitalism.The 2004 election of President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, a former Suharto-era general who has positioned himself as an economic reformer, raised hopes among foreign investors.But while Mr Yudhoyono’s government has launched an unprecedented war against Indonesia’s endemic corruption, the consensus remains that it has been slow to deliver on other investment climate reforms.That may be about to change.Jakarta is expected to sign an agreement on Thursday that will take its environmental dispute with Newmont, the world’s largest gold producer, over the Minahasa Raya mine in North Sulawesi a step closer to resolution – albeit one that will require the US miner to pay $30m over the next 10 years.Economic ministers are also scheduled on Thursday to quietly brief an investment climate working group made up of key bilateral and multilateral donors on plans for what is touted as a re-energised reform agenda.The policy package, work on which began last year, is built around revisions to a controversial draft tax law as well as new labour and investment laws.On top of that is an infrastructure-related policy package designed to resuscitate a stalled $150bn infrastructure investment programme that Mr Yudhoyono’s government launched early last year.According to Indonesian officials and others who work closely with the government, there are also hopeful signs that a final resolution to the longstanding dispute with Exxon-Mobil over the operatorship of the Cepu field in central Java may be moving closer.Officials say it is now in the hands of Boediono, the respected academic who took over as chief economic minister last December.He has been consulting with the president on how to break a deadlock between Pertamina, the state oil company, and ExxonMobil over who should operate the Cepu field.People close to the negotiations say progress has been made in drafting the other components of a joint operating agreement, which could see a deal signed within days.Mr Yudhoyono’s government still faces obstacles to needed reforms. Plans for an electricity tariff increase – something that investors say is badly needed to help attract foreign investment to Indonesia’s ailing power generation sector – face significant political opposition.But analysts say the Newmont settlement, due to be unveiled on Thursday, is at least one concrete example that Jakarta has not lost sight of what it needs to do to lure foreign investors back.“In the end what matters is the direction. Is the government moving in the right direction? And the speed. Is the government moving in that direction fast enough?” said Fauzi Ichsan, Standard Chartered’s chief economist in Jakarta.“There will be different perspectives on the speed. But in the end, everyone agrees the direction is good.”Analysts argue that a partial resolution to the Newmont saga is unlikely to carry the same weight as Jakarta finally resolving the fate of the $2bn Cepu field.The field is expected to add about 170,000 barrels per day to Indonesia’s current production of just under 1m bpd.“Cepu would be a milestone,” said Mr Ichsan.Meanwhile, Newmont still faces a criminal trial over alleged pollution at the Minahasa Raya gold mine that is expected to drag on until June or July.One of the company’s top executives faces a lengthy jail term if he is convicted.The “goodwill agreement” to be signed today also contains a bitter pill – Newmont will pay $30m over 10 years to fund a new community development foundation and monitor both the environment and health of people around the former mine site for a decade.Even Newmont officials, though, say that after months of negotiations and plenty of bad press they see a victory for Mr Yudhoyono’s government in its struggle to convince foreign investors to brave what remains a fraught investment climate.“It’s a great outcome,” one senior Newmont official insisted on Tuesday.“The government is reaffirming its commitment to a climate that is conducive to investment and a climate that is fair to investors. It’s very good for the government.”

Titular: Newmont to pay Indonesia $30m
Texto: Newmont is on Thursday expected to sign an agreement with the Indonesian government that would see the world’s largest gold producer pay $30m over the next 10 years to bring an 18-month-old environmental dispute with Jakarta a step closer to resolution.The deal is likely to be seen as a significant win for President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono and his efforts to bring foreign investment back to south-east Asia’s largest economy. According to data released on Wednesday, Indonesia’s GDP grew by an annualised 4.9 per cent – its slowest growth in six quarters – in the final three months of 2005.The deal is also expected to ease some of the pressure that US-based Newmont has felt over its environmental practices as part of a mounting global campaign against the gold industry.Under the terms of a “goodwill agreement”, Newmont will pay $3m a year over the next 10 years to fund community development projects and scientific monitoring around the site of its now-shut Minahasa Raya mine in North Sulawesi.In return, Jakarta will drop efforts to revive a $135m civil suit it filed against Newmont last year and withdraw an appeal to Indonesia’s Supreme Court against a lower-court ruling that threw out the case last year.Newmont and a senior executive of the company are still the subject of a criminal trial over the same allegations. The agreement could also help the company’s defence in that case.According to people close to both sides, the agreement contains wording that would help partially exonerate Newmont by pointing to conflicting evidence over whether any arsenic, mercury or other heavy-metal pollution occurred near the Minahasa Raya mine.The agreement would not exonerate the miner wholly, and the company is understood to have sought a stronger wording.However, the deal calls for an independent six-person scientific team to be set up to determine whether pollution occurred and to monitor conditions around the site for the next 10 years. The formation of that team, a senior Newmont official said on Wednesday, would provide a “strong scientific underpinning that will confirm that there is no pollution”.Mahendra Siregar, spokesman for Indonesia’s chief economics minister, said the government still believed there had been pollution at Newmont’s operations. But he said Jakarta had decided to set aside the issue. “We don’t want to pursue this in court. We don’t think that is the right way.”Mr Yudhoyono’s government has been trying to re-energise a stalled economic reform programme. The government is due on Thursday to brief key donors on a new investment package that would involve the revamping of a controversial draft tax law and the introduction of new investment and labour laws.Jakarta is understood to be a step closer to resolving a long-running dispute with ExxonMobil over control of a $2bn oilfield in Java.

Titular: Decent earnings help to shrug off commodities dip
Texto: Wall Street put in a resilient performance this week as a number of impressive earnings offset the impact of falling commodity prices which hit energy and mining stocks.The Dow Jones Industrial Average managed to hold on to gains, adding 1.2 per cent over the week to 10,919.05 with the broader S&P 500 edging up 0.2 per cent to 1,266.99 while the Nasdaq eased back a fraction of a point to 2,261.88.Energy stocks slumped along with crude prices after an increase in US stockpiles offset supply concerns from key producers Iran, Nigeria and Venezuela.The S&P energy index was the worst performing industry group, down 4.5 per cent. EGO Resources, the oil and gas exploration company, led the decline, dropping 12.3 per cent over the five sessions to $69.37, while oil majors ExxonMobil and Chevron fell 3.2 per cent to $59.43 and 1.5 per cent to $56.27 respectively.Metal producers and gold miners were not immune to falling commodity prices. With both gold and base metal prices heading south this week, US Steel saw its shares give up 2.8 per cent to $54.80 and gold miner Newmont Mining shed 8.1 per cent to $54.80.Woes were further compounded by losses in the housing sector, following a bearish forecast from luxury housebuilder Toll Brothers.In the latest sign that the US housing market – a principal driver of the US economy in the past couple of years – may have peaked, the company said first quarter sales fell 29 per cent and cut its sales guidance for the full year.Merrill Lynch downgraded the stock from “buy” to “neutral”, while Ian Shepherdson, chief US economist at High Frequency Economics, called the housebuilder’s performance a “seriously startling plunge in activity”.Toll Brothers’ shares fell 7.3 per cent on the week to $29.82, taking their slide since the start of the year to 18.2 per cent.Although not a particularly good week for techs, Cisco Systems, the world’s biggest maker of networking equipment, was a strong performer in the second half of the week after the company’s chief executive delivered an upbeat outlook statement to complement fiscal second-quarter profits which avoided any shocks. Cisco shares were up 8.9 per cent on the week to $19.76.Electronic Data Systems, the computer services company, unveiled fourth-quarter net profit which more than doubled that of the previous year. The company picked up some positive broker comment in spite of falling revenues from General Motors, its biggest customer. EDS shares were up 1.3 per cent on the week to $25.72.Completing a trio of technology movers, software maker Oracle offered guidance on Friday that met with modest approval. The company said that following its merger with Siebel Systems it planned 2,000 job cuts across the combined company. Its shares were little changed on Friday, but rose 3.9 per cent to $12.69 on the week.The Dow was propped up by Walt Disney, which gained after the media conglomerate delivered an unexpected gain in first-quarter profit. News that it had sold off its radio assets to Citadel Broadcasting for $2.7bn further boosted sentiment for the stock, helping it finish the week up 6.7 per cent at $26.68.The blue chip index also found support in Pfizer. Shares in the drugmaker peaked on Wednesday after it said it was considering the sale of its consumer products division, home to well known brands like Listerine and Sudafed. Analysts said the unit might be worth more than $10bn, enabling the company to concentrate more of its energies on pharmaceuticals development and a return to earnings growth in 2006.The company disappointed on Friday however, when it said sales and adjusted earnings for 2006 would only be in line with those of last year as patents expired and generic competition bit. The shares slid 2.5 per cent on Friday, but were up 1.6 per cent on the week to $25.68.General Motors, the troubled carmaker, was once again the worst performer on the Dow this week. Promises of dividend cuts and slashing executive salaries failed to convince investors that unionised workers would accept cuts in wages, benefits and jobs. “There appears to be an ever increasing probability of confrontation with unions,” said Deutsche Bank, which downgraded GM to “sell” from “hold”. The shares fell 5.5 per cent to $21.87.Aon, the world’s second- biggest insurance broker and Spanish-language broadcaster Univision Communications were the top gainers this week on the S&P.Aon jumped 13.1 per cent to $38.11 after it reported that fourth-quarter net income almost tripled while Univision surged 11.1 percent to $34.70 after the company said it was considering a possible sale. CBS and News Corp both expressed interest while Time Warner and Walt Disney were also cited as possible bidders.

Titular: Wall St drained as investors cash in on energy
Texto: Investors cashed in on energy shares on Tuesday, with the broad sell-off in oil producers and drillers pulling Wall Street lower.Crude prices slumped more than $2, or 3 per cent as forecasts of an increase in US petroleum stockpiles overshadowed possible supply concerns from Iran.The Amex oil index plunged 3.4 per cent, led by the 3.5 per cent drop in NYSE-listed shares of UK oil giant BP and ExxonMobil’s 2.3 per cent decline.Oil service providers were hit, with Schlumberger and Halliburton both down more than 5.7 per cent.Metal producers and gold miners were not immune to falling commodity prices. Aluminium maker Alcoa lost 3.6 per cent to $30.87, while shares in gold miner Newmont Mining gave up 6.8 per cent to $56.39.The losses weighed on the S&P 500, which closed down 0.8 per cent at 1,254.78. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.5 per cent to 10,749.76 while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.6 per cent to 2,244.96.The indices’ woes were compounded by weaknesses in the housing sector, which came following a bearish forecast from luxury builder Toll Brothers.In the latest sign that the US housing market was cooling, Toll Brothers said its first-quarter sales had plunged 29 per cent and cut its sales guidance for the full year. Its shares tumbled more than 5.5 per cent to $29.47 while rivals DR Horton and Pulte Homes fell 3.7 per cent to $33.67 and2.3 per cent to $37.07 respectively.Toll’s warning cast a shadow on home improvement retailers with Home Depot dropping 1.6 per cent to $38.86 and Lowes falling 1.7 per cent to $61.87.Meanwhile, technology stocks continued to be a focus ahead of fourth-quarter results from internet equipment maker Cisco Systems, due after the close. Cisco shares were up 1.5 per cent at $18.09 in spite of talk that the bellwether would deliver lower sales guidance for fiscal 2006.By contrast, Google failed to impress investors with a new version of its Gmail e-mail service. Shares in the search engine continued to suffer from renewed selling, losing 4.5 per cent to $367.92.Losses on the Dow were limited by Walt Disney, which surged 7 per cent to $26.70 after the media conglomerate delivered an unexpected gain in first-quarter profit. The stock was further buoyed by news that Citadel Broadcasting had agreed to acquire its radio assets in a deal valued at $2.7bn.Better than expected quarterly earnings lifted shares of soft drink giant Coca-Cola, up 0.2 per cent at $41.03, and power supplies maker Emerson Electric, up 2.7 per cent at $78.96.General Motors agreed to cut its quarterly dividend in half and reduce executive pay after reporting $8.5bn in losses last year.Its shares fell 2.3 per cent to $22.81 as investors questioned whether the move would help halt its slide.

Titular: Mining counts the cost of cleaning up its image
Texto: Mining has an image problem. In developing and developed countries alike, the public tends to regard the industry as dirty, dangerous and disruptive – and those who stand to profit from it as greedy despoilers.But as gold, copper and other metals hit their highest prices for many years, and the power generation industry is poised for a big shift from gas to coal, the imperative to challenge that caricature is becoming more urgent.While mine companies are making record profits, and mining stocks are attracting swaths of new investors, the risk of reputational damage is also rising as easy-to-reach deposits of metals, coal and diamonds in locations such as Australia and Canada are exhausted, forcing mining companies to expand into more remote areas of Africa, Asia and Latin America.The critical voices are loud and well organised. But the industry is fighting back – admitting to past failings but trumpeting the message that, at a time when many fund managers use corporate social responsibility as an important criterion for investment, it has cleaned up its act.Fierce criticism of the environmental and social impact of mining is nothing new. The industry has long had a reputation for making large profits in poor countries and leaving nothing but environmental and social havoc in its wake.Typical of the protest movement is Earthworks, a US-based non-governmental organisation that since 2004 has been running a campaign called No Dirty Gold. It accuses gold producers of using cyanide to recover greater amounts of metal and of wrecking traditional ways of life. Like many NGOs, it argues that poor but mineral-rich countries are held back by the “resource curse”: profits from mining enrich foreign companies and a small, corrupt elite in government but not local communities.Bobby Godsell, chief executive of AngloGold Ashanti of South Africa, one of the world’s largest gold producers, argues that mining is no more inherently harmful than any other form of economic activity. But he admits that not all companies are responsible corporate citizens. “There is the possibility of ‘good mining’ – and you can find good projects all over the world. But there are also bad projects,” he acknowledges.In the 1960s, the mining industry pursued growth at all costs. The result was accidents and environmental damage. But in the 1970s the strategy began to be questioned. Mr Godsell says pressure from governments, NGOs and shareholders was pivotal although he argues that executives’ consciences also played a part.But far from abating, protest movements have grown, in part because the internet has opened avenues of complaint to once-disenfranchised communities. Recent examples of anti-mining protests include objections to the Rio Blanco copper project in Peru, owned by Monterrico Metals of London, and hostility encountered by Newmont, the US gold producer, in Indonesia. In 2001, several big mining companies decided that action was needed to tackle their industry’s poor image. They formed the International Council on Mining and Metals, a grouping that styles itself as “the responsible face of mining”.This made good business sense, companies say. As graduates increasingly shun “old” industries, the mining sector is facing a shortage of new talent and companies hope a rehabilitation of the industry’s reputation could help attract young blood.In its first five years the ICMM has had plenty to keep it busy. While accidents are less frequent than they used to be, issues of waste disposal and the use of toxic chemicals remain. Newmont is currently locked in a battle with local people, NGOs and politicians in Indonesia over whether the gold company dumped toxic waste into Buyat Bay, near its now-closed Minahasa Raya mine, and consequently poisoned villagers. Newmont admits to dumping the waste but insists it had been treated and was harmless. Wayne Murdy, chief executive of Newmont, has since said the dispute was more to do with a breakdown in relations with the local community than the environment itself.An example of ICMM’s proactive approach concerns cyanide – which, though highly toxic, is widely used in the recovery of gold because it allows metal to be retrieved from low-grade ore. In an attempt to ease criticism of the chemical, the ICMM has developed the “Cyanide Code”, a voluntary list of guidelines for the safe application of the poison in gold mining.It is not simply reputations that are at stake. The World Bank, through its International Finance Corporation arm, controversially helps finance mining and oil and gas projects around the world. But access to the funding depends on companies’ capacity to make a convincing case that their approach to the environment and affected communities is “sustainable”, in the jargon.In 2004, the Extractive Industries Review, an independent report commissioned by the World Bank, recommended a halt to this funding, because of the industries’ negative side-effects. The bank rejected this recommendation and pledged to fund more projects than ever. But it undertook to get involved with projects earlier, so its standards on the environment and community engagement were met.Rashad Kaldany, director of oil, gas, mining and chemicals at the World Bank/IFC, insists past problems have been resolved, maintaining: “The use of cyanide should not be an issue in a well-run mine today.” But he says communities near to mines “have legitimate worries” based on past pollution incidents. Again, the problem often boils down to a lack of communication between mining companies and local people. If mining companies go against their natural instinct to keep a low profile, and try to engage local communities, protests can be avoided, says the World Bank.There are some signs that companies’ claims to have got to grips with the environmental side-effects of what they do in recent years are well-founded. They are making more efforts to study the ecosystem in an area before they start work and to limit the damage that mining does to plant and animal life. Generally, the industry is starting to compile better environmental data – on water quality, for example – before mines are built. The World Bank is encouraging this, in part so they can counter any subsequent accusations of pollution.Perhaps the most striking example of a company that has sought to shed a reputation for environmental irresponsibility is Rio Tinto of the UK. It spent several years working on the preservation of biodiversity before proceeding with its controversial ilmenite project in Fort-Dauphin, Madagascar.This represents a big cultural shift. As one of the first large diversified mining companies listed on the London Stock Exchange, Rio Tinto was for many years the bête-noire of environmental groups, who used regularly to picket its annual shareholder meetings. “It is ridiculous to say that mining is not intrusive for the environment – but we can minimise the intrusiveness,” says Andrew Vickerman, Rio Tinto’s head of communication and sustainable development. The company has got better at explaining itself, he says, and he talks to a full range of NGOs, from well-established organisations such as Oxfam and Greenpeace to more radical groups. “Our approach to engagement changed about a decade ago. There was a realisation that reputation is hugely important.” There is a clear commercial pay-off, he acknowledges. “If we prove we can mine responsibly, it will get us access to new resources.”Mr Kaldany at the World Bank says that “many of the most important players in the industry take the issue of sustainable development very seriously” but smaller mining companies do not always adhere to the new standards. Mr Vickerman at Rio Tinto accepts that this is a problem for the sector. “The mining industry is judged by its worst performers and there are some real cowboys out there.”Now a new front is opening up for the industry: the need to tackle the social fall-out from its activities. That can range from the spread of HIV/Aids by migrant workers to increased government corruption and broader questions about whether indigenous populations are reaping an appropriate share of the spoils.Critics point out that examples of communities made rich by mining are sparse. Botswana’s economy has grown fast as a result of revenues from diamond mining but, even there, people are worried about what will happen to the economy after the mines are closed. The World Bank is encouraging the development of other types of economic activity in mining regions, so that people are not so dependent on finite mineral resources.But investors may query whether a need to appease environmental and social campaigners is leading companies to assume a role that more properly belongs to governments.In the poorest countries, mining companies often find themselves building infrastructure such as roads, schools and hospitals. Not surprisingly, these companies are sometimes attacked as proxies for the government. In such cases, the World Bank is pursuing a policy of “capacity building”, a mixture of education, training and anti-corruption measures. Although it is not mining companies’ responsibility to ensure governments function properly, it is in their interests, the bank argues.Mr Kaldany says mining companies should focus on winning local support. For example, jobs should go to local, rather than imported workers. “If local communities do not feel they are benefiting from mining, I don’t think the image of the industry will change.”There are signs that investors agree. Todd Warren, who manages mining and energy stocks for First State Investments, says he would avoid investing in a company that had put aside insufficient money to cover environmental issues, especially for the clean-up of the site after closure. “The mining industry can no longer operate without taking environmental issues into consideration. If they do, these issues will come back and hurt them.”Although an eye should be kept on corporate costs, Mr Warren says, the increasing amount devoted to the environmental and social side of mining is money well spent. It protects both against accidents and community protests.“Bad publicity has a huge cost,” he says.RIO TINTO’S TORTUOUS PATH TO TREAD ON LEMUR ISLANDBy John ReedOn a strip of rainforest in southern Madagascar, women pluck and repot seedlings destined to revive ravaged surrounding woodland. The variety of seed shapes, sizes and colours attests to the diversity of local flora. About 85 per cent of Madagascar’s plants are unique to the east African island; many exist on just one scrap of land.“There are only nine trees like this left,” says Manon Vincelette, holding up a palmful of knobbly seeds from the genus Eligmocarpus. While studying the forest near the port city of Fort-Dauphin, her team discovered about 10 plant species, a gecko and a snake that were unknown before.The Canadian is the environmental manager for Rio Tinto’s QIT Madagascar Minerals (QMM) project, which will soon begin mining ilmenite, used to whiten paint, plastics and paper. Ms Vincelette has been helping lay the groundwork for a decade and commands a staff of 60. She receives advice from a 10-member biodiversity committee that includes a representative of London’s Kew Gardens and an expert in lemurs, the primates unique to Madagascar.“Without the company, this forest probably wouldn’t be here,” she says of the 230 hectare (568 acre) forest. The claim is credible: local residents are felling other forests for charcoal or slash-and-burn agriculture.Rio Tinto plans to invest $585m (£331m, €483m) in the mining project, Madagascar’s biggest inward investment. Due to yield the business-friendly government about $20m a year in royalties, it will also bequeath a port capable of handling other exports and cruise ships.But because of the risks to the island’s biodiversity, QMM’s history has been tortuous and Rio Tinto has been under severe criticism from environmental campaigning groups. The company hired Ms Vincelette from Conservation International and Lisa Dean, a former country director for the charity Care, to examine the project’s social impact. It has studied everything from butterflies to local demand for charcoal and the potential spread of HIV brought by workers who will build the port, and helped start an organisation for Fort-Dauphin’s sex workers.The project illustrates the lengths to which mining companies need to go to minimise the impact of their fundamentally “dirty” business. Rio Tinto has in the past faced warranted criticism for despoiling regions where it mined. But QMM’s relationship with non-governmental organisations has gone from antagonistic to largely co-operative. Taking on board criticism from the NGOs and local communities, the company moved the location of the port and pledged not to mine on the endangered piece of forest where Ms Vincelette’s team runs the nursery, equivalent to about 10 per cent of the mining deposit.“The main turning point in our environmental partnership with NGOs came when we said, ‘We’ll set aside 10 per cent of this valuable mineral – and reduce our return – to protect the forest’,” says Guy Larin, QMM’s director-general. The project sets a precedent, he adds, “we hope not just in economics but in environmental and social responsibility”.Friends of the Earth, the pressure group, still claims it will damage biodiversity and bring local people little benefit. But WWF, the environmental charity, after a critical view in 2001 now supports the project, with qualifications. “On balance, it’s very favourable to the region and favourable to Madagascar in general,” says Martin Nicoll, senior conservation adviser for WWF in Madagascar. He retains concerns about dust, chemical and noise pollution but says the project will “create huge opportunities for direct employment and associated services”.Assessments and consultations resulted in the signing of a dina, a traditional social contract binding the company and local communities to meet certain obligations. Building the port is due to start this year andQMM will employ up to 1,000 foreign workers at a time as the project reaches its peak over the next three years. They will be confined largely to a purpose-built village and held to a code of conduct. “We can’t stop all fraternisation but we can put all the firewalls in place,” says Ms Dean.The company has linked with donors on HIV programmes. Ms Dean admits that some preparations may be insufficient – or beyond the call of duty. “There’s really no benchmark as to what’s enough.”ACCIDENTS WILL HAPPEN■ 2006: A shaft collapse this month at the Sago coal mine in West Virginia, owned by International Coal Group, killed 12. The mine had previous alleged safety breaches.■ 2000: A truck transporting mercury from Newmont’s Yanacocha gold mine spilled its cargo over a road in Peru. People who scooped up the poisonous liquid later had problems from blindness to memory loss.■ 1998: A break in the wall of a waste dam at the Los Frailes zinc/copper/lead/silver mine in Spain sent contaminated water into the Rio Agrio and the Guadiamar river near Seville. The clean-up took seven months and cost more than $100m.■ Early 1990s: At the Summitville gold mine in Colorado a cyanide leaching facility started leaking soon after operations started. The US Environmental Protection Agency had to foot the clean-up bill after Galactic Resources of Canada, the mine’s owner, went bankrupt.

Titular: Wall St rallies on consumer confidence
Texto: Wall Street staged a gentle rally on Wednesday, lifted by news of higher-than-expected improvement in consumer confidence in December and a late surge in holiday spending.The signs of strength in the US economy trumped concern among investors about an inversion of the treasury yield curve.For a second consecutive day, yields on 10-year US Treasury briefly dipped below those on two-year paper. The inversion has historically heralded the start of a slowdown in the US economy. But in contrast to Tuesday’s frenzied sell-off, investors appeared unfazed by the renewed convergence.The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended the session 0.2 per cent higher at 10,796.26, while the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite both ticked up 1 per cent to 1,258.17 and 2,228.94 respectively.Energy stocks, which rebounded along with crude prices, helped keep the Dow afloat. The Amex oil index gained 1.6 per cent, while the energy-price-sensitive Amex airline index dropped 2.4 per cent.Gold companies also advanced after the price of bullion hit a two-week high. Newmont Mining, the world’s biggest gold producer, climbed 3.5 per cent to $53.40 while Freeport-McMoRan Cooper & Gold, owner of the world’s biggest gold mine, rose 2.6 per cent to $54.88.On the Nasdaq, gains in eBay, up 1.4 per cent at $44.37, helped offset losses in Apple Computers. Shares in the iPod maker, which have seen intense demand this year, pulled back 0.9 per cent to $73.57 on valuation concerns. Elsewhere, retailers were in focus after the International Council of Shopping Centers said US retail chains’ same-store sales rose 2.8 per cent last week.However, Target dashed shareholders’ hopes for a robust holiday sales season after it said December same-store sales only rose in line with previous guidance. Its shares dipped 0.1 per cent to $55.55. Meanwhile, rival Wal-Mart advanced 0.2 per cent to $47.84.By contrast, Linens ’n Things, the home furnishing retailer, surged 10.9 per cent to $26.52 on news that the private equity firm Apollo Capital Management was preparing to complete its acquisition of the company.Albertson’s, the grocery chain, climbed 1.3 per cent to $21.10 after JPMorgan upgraded its rating on the stock. The broker said that the collapse of takeover talks last week would open the door for shareholder activists.Drugmaker Celgene jumped 5.9 per cent to $60.85 after the Food and Drug Administration approved its anaemia drug Revlimid.AstraZeneca, the UK’s second largest drugmaker, traded up 0.9 per cent to $48.85 after it signed a $300m research and licensing agreement with Targacept to develop and market an experimental treatment for Alzheimer’s disease and schizophrenia.

Titular: Barrick agrees to buy Placer Dome for $10.4bn
Texto: Vancouver-based Placer Dome has agreed a sweetened $10.4bn cash-and-shares takeover bid by Barrick Gold of Toronto, setting the stage for Barrick to overtake Newmont Mining as the world's biggest gold producer.Peter Tomsett, Placer's chief executive, said on Thursday that the improved bid “addresses the inadequacies” of Barrick's initial $9.2bn offer, which it made in late October.Placer has agreed to pay Barrick a break-up fee of up to $260m if a superior bid emerges. Mr Tomsett said that Placer had held talks with a number of other prospective bidders.The deal underlines the snowballing rate of consolidation in the global mining industry. Barrick's chief executive Greg Wilkins said that “we didn't do this just to be the biggest. We did it to be more competitive in the industry.”Terms have also been improved of a side deal to spin off some Placer assets, mainly in northern Ontario, to Goldcorp, a smaller Toronto-based gold producer. Goldcorp will now pay $1.49bn, up from $1.35bn.Barrick and Placer are expected to produce a combined 8.3m-8.4m ounces of gold this year, with reserves totalling 150m ounces.Newmont's 2005 output is estimated at about 7.4m ounces.Barrick and Placer own several mines and exploration properties close to one another in Nevada, western Australia, Chile and Tanzania. Total cost savings from joint management of these properties were estimated at $240m a year when Barrick made its initial offer.Mr Wilkins said on Thursday that additional synergies had been found since then, but he declined to be specific.According to Mr Wilkins, Barrick intends to keep Placer's portfolio of mines intact.But he added that Barrick had “an open mind” about the future of Placer's 50 per cent stake in the big South Deep mine in South Africa, which has been dogged by high costs and low production.South Deep would be Barrick's first foray into South Africa. “We intend to spend some time fully understanding the asset and its opportunities”, Mr Wilkins said.Placer earlier criticised Barrick's relatively large hedged position and long delays in developing the Pascua-Lama project on the Argentina-Chile border.But Mr Tomsett said on Thursday that the Vancouver company “now understands Barrick's perspective” on these issues. Placer has been considered a takeover target for some time.A sharp rise in operating costs at some of its mines has more than offset the recent jump in the gold price, leading to a drop in earnings and a lower share price. Placer's third-quarter earnings shrank by 77 per cent.Barrick shares ended the day off by 0.3 per cent, and Placer's stock lost 1.3 per cent following the wake of Thursday's announcement.

Titular: Observer - US
Texto: On the sidelines of the gold boomThe top brass at Barrick Gold should have been laughing all the way to the bank on Monday as the gold price shot to $540 an ounce, its highest level in a quarter century. The Toronto-based gold producer’s shares climbed above $28, about a third higher than they were six months ago.Instead, long faces abounded at Barrick’s head office. Senior officers are barred from exercising their stock options pending the outcome of Barrick’s $9.2bn hostile bid for Placer Dome of Vancouver. “Just when one would probably have exercised some, we are blacked-out,” grumbled one manager.The Barrick folks have the consolation that two of their counterparts at Placer may be feeling even more sore. Jim Cooney, Placer’s vice president for international government affairs, and John Loney, vice president for risk management, each cashed in a chunk of their options a day or two after Barrick announced its bid on October 31.They both sold at under $20. Placer’s shares were trading on Monday at more than $23, with rumours rampant that Barrick will jack up its offer or that Newmont Mining of Denver is about to join the fray.Having played down expectations that this week’s meeting in Hong Kong will make any big breakthroughs in the stalled Doha round talks, World Trade Organisation members have been casting around for something to keep them busy and to show that their journeys were not entirely unnecessary.Their big idea is a package of measures intended to benefit poor countries and persuade them that this really is a “development round”.How much good it will do is uncertain. But at least Hong Kong’s economy stands to gain. Its government is budgeting US$33m for the meeting, and local businesses are chipping in a further $7m towards the cost. The tourist board says that on average, visitors attending conferences spend $284 a day each. If all 11,000 registered participants show up and stay the full six days, that should see $19m rolling in.Then, of course, there are the bills for air travel. Assuming average fares of $2,000 each, that will add a further $22m. By Observer’s tally, that makes a grand total of more than $80m, almost as much as the WTO’s annual budget.For that sort of money, the meeting had better come up with something that makes a real dent in global poverty.One conspicuous absentee from this week’s meeting will be Mogens Peter Carl, veteran European Commission trade warrior and long a thorn in the side of Brussels’ WTO partners. Dubbed Darth Vader by US trade diplomats, the imperious Dane is legendary for his aggressive negotiating methods and ability to rub people up the wrong way.Carl even managed to antagonise his own side. At the WTO’s last ministerial meeting, in Cancún two years ago, several EU ministers grumbled that he had failed to consult them properly, brushing aside their advice and insisting on taking a hard line in the talks.When developing countries walked out of the talks, causing them to collapse, some European officials blamed the debacle partly on Carl’s intransigence.Peter Mandelson, trade commissioner and Carl’s boss, lost patience with him soon after taking office a year ago. After dropping veiled public hints that the great Dane had got too big for his boots, not least after a leaked letter from Carl accusing Mandy of being swayed by celebrity trade justice campaigners such as Bono, Mandelson succeeded in drafting in David O’Sullivan, a less abrasive Irishman.Carl was shuffled off to a lesser job as head of the environment directorate. That may mean stormy weather ahead for international climate change talks. But it should improve the atmosphere at the talks.There is not much any delegate can do about the atmosphere outside the conference centre.A poisonous smog – coyly referred to as “haze” by politically correct weather forecasters and Cathay Pacific airline pilots – often blankets the city at this time of year, when the wind blows in from the tens of thousands of factories in the Chinese province of Guangdong to the north.In the city centre on Monday, airborne particles – soot and dust, that is – and nitrogen dioxide each hit the level described by Hong Kong’s Environmental Protection Department as “very high”. That means those with heart or breathing problems are advised to stay inside.It must be comforting for WTO negotiators to know that they are no worse off in smoke-filled discussion rooms than they would be outside in the open air.Hong Kong’s government has gone to enormous lengths to ensure security. The police will deploy one third of the 27,000-strong force, and the government has been busy drawing up multiple scenarios for dealing with violent protests.Office buildings near the convention centre in Wanchai are wrapped in protective wire netting, some companies have stocked up on instant noodles for hungry staff who might get trapped in the building, and others have set up facilities for staff to work from home or elsewhere if necessary. Banks and government offices plan to shorten their hours, many shops will close, and even the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has moved more than 100 dogs and cats out of its local office.Some people are staying put, though. One plucky local is flying a flag in the city centre saying “Hong Kong loves capitalism”. As a local restaurant owner put it: “Protesters need to eat too”.

Titular: Placer Dome calls Barrick offer too low
Texto: Placer Dome of Canada on Wednesday rejected a US$9.2bn hostile bid from Barrick Gold, its larger domestic rival, saying the offer was too low and carried too many risks for investors. Placer said it was now talking to other groups about a deal, rumoured to include Newmont of the US.Toronto-based Barrick, the world’s third-largest gold producer after Newmont and AngloGold Ashanti of South Africa, made its unsolicited cash and shares bid for Vancouver-based Placer on October 31.Robert Franklin, Placer’s chairman, said on Wednesday that his group’s board had taken “a long, hard look at Barrick’s bid and found it lacking many respects”. He said the board was unanimous in its decision to reject the bid, which undervalued Placer and was made opportunistically at a time when Placer’s shares were underperforming Barrick stock.Peter Tomsett, Placer’s chief executive, said: “It is clear why Barrick would want to buy Placer Dome, but why would Placer want to do a deal with Barrick?”Placer had a strong pipeline of mine development projects and was increasing its gold production, while Barrick was finding it hard to replace its gold reserves, he added.Barrick said on Wednesday it did not intend to increase its offer, which it described as “full and fair”.Barrick needs to receive acceptances from 66.66 per cent of Placer’s shareholders by December 20 for its bid to be successful.If the deal goes ahead, Placer’s shareholders would be left with about 35 per cent of the merged entity. Mr Tomsett said this was risky for Placer investors, and would leave them exposed to future drops in Barrick’s share price. He said there was uncertainty surrounding Barrick’s gold hedging policy, and also on the viability of certain Barrick projects, such as the Pascua-Lama deposit on the border of Chile and Argentina. Placer’s management will be visiting shareholders over the next few weeks in an effort to discourage them from tendering their shares to Barrick.Placer is the fifth-biggest gold producer in the world and a combination of the two companies would form the world’s largest gold company, overtaking Newmont.The group has for some time been considered a takeover target, and a sharp rise in operating costs has more than offset the recent jump in the gold price, leading to a drop in earnings.Barrick has said its offer would produce cost savings of about $240m a year because of synergies between the companies’ mines and exploration properties, located close to one another in Nevada, West Australia, Chile and Tanzania.Mr Tomsett said that Placer had opened a data room for other potential bidders, and that there was “significant interest”. It has been reported that Newmont was one of the companies weighing up a bid. The US company declined to comment.

Titular: Indonesian court dismisses suit against Newmont
Texto: An Indonesian court on Tuesday threw out a $133m suit brought against the world’s largest gold miner Newmont in what is likely to be seen as a significant victory for foreign investors in south-east asia’s largest economy.The lawsuit was brought by the government of President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono earlier this year as a result of a dispute over alleged pollution at a now-shut Newmont mine in Sulawesi Province.But its dismissal on technical grounds by a Jakarta court is a victory for Newmont as well as foreign investors who complain that Indonesia’s courts often disregard internationally binding contracts. The court ruled that the government had erred by filing a lawsuit rather than going to arbitration as called for in Jakarta’s contract with Newmont.Newmont still faces criminal proceedings against it and Richard Ness, a senior executive, in connection with its Minahasa Raya gold mine in Sulawesi.Newmont has been accused of contaminating with heavy metals a bay near the mine into which it disposed of treated mining waste while it was in operation. But Newmont argues that studies by bodies such as the World Health Organisation show no pollution occurred.Newmont has come under attack from environmentalists for its practices in Indonesia, Peru and elsewhere.In Indonesia the case has also been watched closely by foreign investors amid promises from Mr Yudhoyono and his government that they want to improve what is seen as a sometimes hostile environment for foreign capital.Jakarta and Newmont have been in negotiations over the civil lawsuit for months. A potential agreement is understood to hinge on the company establishing a fund to help villagers and extend environmental monitoring in the area.The company on Tuesday welcomed the ruling. “It’s a real positive,” said Bob Gallagher, Newmont’s vice president in charge of Indonesian operations.Mr Gallagher said negotiations with the government would continue despite Tuesday’s ruling. “The dispute does still exist,” he said after the verdict. “The Ministry of Environment thinks we polluted and we believe that we didn’t.”The environment ministry said Tuesday it might appeal or take its case to another forum.“It’s very clear that [the other mining companies] were all watching this trial,” said a western observer.“If Richard Ness gets convicted – even if he doesn’t serve a day in prison – that will have a very chilling effect on foreign willingness to do business here,” he said.

Titular: Barrick Gold offers $9.2bn for Placer Dome
Texto: The consolidation of the global mining industry accelerated on Monday when Barrick Gold launched an unsolicited $9.2bn cash-and-stock bid for Placer Dome, its Canadian rival.A deal would make Toronto-based Barrick the world’s biggest gold producer. However, Placer is widely expected to seek improved terms for a deal by looking for a white knight.Placer, based in Vancouver, has for some time been considered a takeover target. A sharp rise in operating costs has more than offset the recent jump in the gold price, leading to a drop in earnings and a lower share price. Placer’s third quarter earnings shrank 77 per cent.Greg Wilkins, Barrick’s chief executive, on Monday said the two companies had held “a number of conversations over the years and never had much traction from them”.The combined company would produce 8.3m-8.4m ounces of gold and 370m pounds of copper a year. Newmont Mining, the biggest producer, has projected 2005 output of 7.4m ounces.Mr Wilkins said Barrick would benefit from synergies between the companies’ mines and exploration properties. Cost savings are estimated at $240m a year.The deal would give Barrick its first foothold in South Africa, where Placer has a 50 per cent stake in the South Deep mine.Mr Wilkins said Barrick wanted to “revisit” the Cerro Casale deposit in Chile, which Placer said recently was not viable. Placer announced a deal last week to sell its stake in Cerro Casale.Barrick has struck a separate deal to spin off some Placer assets, mainly in northern Ontario, to Goldcorp, a smaller Toronto-based gold producer, for about $1.35bn in cash. The Placer and Goldcorp properties in Ontario are often mentioned as obvious candidates for consolidation.Placer shareholders can choose to receive $20.50 in cash or 0.7518 of a Barrick common share plus 5 cents in cash for each Placer share. Barrick has limited the cash portion of its bid to $1.22bn. The bid requires approval by holders of two-thirds of Placer’s shares.Barrick shares were down 5.7 per cent to $25.65 in afternoon trading in New York on Monday. Placer shares jumped 19.9 per cent to $19.79.

Titular: Barrick makes a bid for supremacy
Texto:
One analyst on Monday described Barrick’s hostile $9.2bn bid for compatriot rival Placer Dome as “a bid for supremacy in the gold industry”.If successful, Barrick would leap frog its main rival, Newmont of the US, and would become the world’s largest producer of gold.Greg Wilkins, Barrick’s chief executive, on Monday appealed to Placer Dome shareholders’ patriotic instincts. “This deal will take Barrick to the next level and will form a leading Canadian gold company, best able to compete on the world stage.”Placer Dome’s acquisition could revive the process of consolidation in the gold sector, following several false starts in the last 18 months.Last May, Iamgold of Canada failed to merge with Wheaton River, also of
Canada, after the hostile intervention of Golden Star of the US.Iamgold went on to agree a deal with Gold Fields of South Africa. But this was foiled by a hostile bid for Gold Fields from Harmony Gold of South Africa.
Harmony’s audacious attempt to buy its larger compatriot failed earlier this year after a bruising and lengthy battle.The combination of the two South African companies would have created
the world’s largest gold group.Barrick and Newmont have long vied for the top position in the gold industry, and analysts said Barrick’s surprise bid for Placer Dome could spur Newmont to launch a rival offer.The larger gold companies are finding its increasingly difficult to expand their gold reserves, and to replace the gold being dug from the ground each year. A lack of spending on gold exploration between 1997 and 2002, because of the low gold price, meant that few new discoveries were made.Although Barrick has a strong project pipeline covering the next few years, one reason for its interest in Placer Dome is to get access to deposits and exploration projects that can be turned into mines in the longer term, from 2009 onwards. “One of the most exciting aspects of this deal is the pipeline of projects,” said Mr Wilkins.The combined exploration talent of the two companies would be “a juggernaut of an exploration team”, according to Alex Davidson, Barrick’s head of exploration.Another possible white knight for Placer Dome is AngloGold Ashanti of South Africa. AngloGold is 51 per cent owned by Anglo American, the diversified mining group, but its parent said last week that it was retreating from the gold business and would reduce its stake in the company.This gives AngloGold more freedom to pursue mergers and acquisitions, as it does not need permission from Anglo American. A deal with Placer Dome would give Anglo American a good opportunity to exit its investment in AngloGold, and there may be some synergies between Placer’s South Deep mine in South Africa and AngloGold’s operations nearby.However, analysts said on Monday that AngloGold might not have a strong enough balance sheet to pursue a deal this year.One of Barrick’s main arguments for a combination with Placer is that both companies operate in similar parts of the world, and
synergies in transport, procurement and management could save $240m a year from 2007.The assets of both companies are concentrated in North America, mainly in Nevada; in Australia, centred around Kalgoorlie; in Tanzania, and in South America, on the Chile-Argentina border.Mr Wilkins said on Monday that Barrick is the lowest cost gold producer among the larger companies, with costs of around $210 per ounce of metal.Placer has been less successful at cutting costs, and the average cost for the combined group would be between $245 and $250 per ounce, but synergies would reduce this over time, he said.As well as having the largest reserves of gold in the world, a combined
Barrick and Placer Dome would also have the largest hedgebook.GFMS, the London-based metals consultancy, said Barrick was already the largest hedger in the gold market, with almost 14m ounces of forward sales.Placer Dome has a hedge book of around 8m ounces. Gold companies are generally reducing their amount of hedging so they can take advantage of the rising gold price.Mr Wilkins said on Monday he would “continue to work to bring the hedge position down and simplify it”.

Titular: Peru's mining areas haunted by the spectre of violence
Texto: President Alejandro Toledo and his Peruvian cabinet gathered for a gala lunch last month for a bout of back-slapping. The administration was celebrating an achievement: annual exports had doubled to more than $14bn since it took office in July 2001.The economy has been carefully managed by a team of technocrats, but the export boom may have less to do with policy than with the high price of minerals, driven by China's hunger. As a producer of copper, gold, silver, zinc and molybdenum, Peru has benefited: the mining sector accounts for half of the country's exports.But the figures hide a trend for the industry in Peru: rising violence directed at mining and exploration companies that threatens to alienate the foreign investors whose input is needed to fuel growth.The latest target is Monterrico Metals, a British resource development company that is developing Rio Blanco, 550 miles north-west of Lima in a farming region on the Ecuadorean border. The project is expected to become Peru's second biggest copper mine when it opens in 2008.In recent weeks the site has come under attack from protesters who say mining will contaminate water supplies to local farms. One demonstrator died in clashes with police last week. Farmers kidnapped three of Monterrico's Peruvian employees in the area last weekend, one of whom has still not been released.The conflict at Rio Blanco follows several similar confrontations. In May, BHP Billiton, the world's biggest diversified miner, suspended operations for a month at its Tintaya mine in southern Peru when protestors raided the site, demanding the company spend more on improving local roads.Last September, Newmont, the US miner, scrapped a planned expansion of Yanacocha, the world's most productive gold mine, in the northern highlands, after demonstrators alleging water contamination besieged the site for two weeks, forcing Newmont to helicopter in shift workers.There have been lower-profile stand-offs: the government reported 12 serious conflicts between mining companies and local communities last month alone.The government says activists in the communist Patria Roja party, radical local clerics and leftwing campaigning groups have whipped up sentiment against Rio Blanco.The police say opium producers in the region encourage violence to prevent the state taking a more active role there. The area is thought to be a centre of poppy cultivation. Many in the industry blame the government for failing to provide security at mines or the infrastructure necessary for development. Andrew Bristow, Monterrico's operations manager, says that the authorities have been helpful since the conflict began, but that the government has a “very poor presence” in the region. “It's almost a forgotten corner of Peru,” he says.José de Echave, of CooperAcción, a Peruvian sustainable development organisation supported by Christian Aid, points to communities' lack of confidence both in mining companies and in the government's ability to oversee their activity.“The ministry of mining is responsible for regulating the environmental impact of the industry, but it also has to attract foreign investment,” he says. “We need a more independent body, like the Environmental Protection Agency in the US.”Part of the problem is big mining's record. “There is a history of poorly run operations in Peru,” says Mr Bristow. Monterrico may be suffering from being near Tambogrande, a project aborted by Manhattan Minerals, a Canadian company that suffered from poor community relations.Peru is witnessing rising social unrest in the run-up to elections next year, much of it directed against local governments or, where government is absent, against companies.In highland areas, where poverty and illiteracy are high, imagined grievances can take root. Some local farmers say Rio Blanco has polluted their water. That is almost certainly untrue, as the project is at the feasibility stage.Some in the industry want it to be more active in countering misinformation.“Most Peruvians don't appreciate what a large role mining plays in the economy,” says Mr Bristow. “We need to do a lot more to defend ourselves.”

Titular: Mining groups struggle to operate in Peru
Texto: Julia Guarniz, a street vendor in the Peruvian highland village of Choropampa, watches blankly as a seven-vehicle convoy thunders past. “They scare me,” she says, pointing at the “hazardous materials” signs on the sides of the juggernauts. “When I see them, I worry that it might happen again.”Similar convoys carry toxic material through the town several times a day on the degraded highway that runs some 600km from Yanacocha, the world's most productive gold mine, to the port of Callao in Lima.Five years ago this week, one truck spilled 330lb of liquid mercury over more than 20km of the road. Attracted to what looked “like a liquid mirror”, the residents of Choropampa collected the mercury and took it home, unknowingly exposing themselves to the highly toxic substance.What has happened since depends on who is telling the story. Newmont, the world's biggest gold miner and Yanacocha's owner, says it has faced up to its responsibility, pumped millions of dollars into clean-up and compensation, and put in place fail-safe safety standards.The villagers do not deny the pay-outs, but say they are still suffering from Newmont's negligence. Thousands complain of neurological and skin conditions, and they say the medical insurance they have been given does not cover the cost of their prescriptions. That insurance runs out this year.Hatred for the mine runs deep. It is difficult to find a resident who will acknowledge having received compensation.The facts may be settled in Denver, Colorado, Newmont's hometown, where 1,100 Choropampa villagers are pursuing the miner through the courts.Ken Crowder, a lawyer representing the victims, says the first cases may be heard this year, potentially providing the basis for a group settlement.What is indisputable is that for many, Choropampa remains a symbol of a perceived environmental and social myopia among international mining companies operating in Peru and their failure to secure a “social licence” from local communities.This was powerfully illustrated last September, when a proposed expansion of Yanacocha met such fierce opposition that the project was abandoned. Local residents claimed that mining Cerro Quilish, a mountain overlooking the town of Cajamarca, would have contaminated their drinking water. Newmont disputes this.But that misses the totemic importance of the battle, fuelled by a feeling among some locals that the company has not given enough to the community.“Quilish became an icon,” says Emilio Horna, mayor of Cajamarca. “Newmont didn't explain enough what they wanted to do.” Guy Landsdown, Yanacocha's operations manager, says the miner “has got a lot of work to do on the social front”. Newmont has joined several local “dialogue roundtables”. In Minas Conga, a new project, it has managed to develop good community relations.Even Yanacocha's opponents concede it has improved environmental standards. Last year it spent $50m (€40.9m, £27.5m) on a reverse osmosis plant to clean discharged water, $20m on dams to prevent sediment seeping into rivers, and $6.5m on other environmental programmes.The company has also created about 4,500 jobs in Cajamarca, one of Peru's poorest regions. It estimates that another 24,000 local jobs depend on the mine. The investment is welcomed by many: Ama Cajamarca, a group funded by the local chamber of commerce, attracted 10,000 locals to a recent demonstration in support of Yanacocha.But it has also spawned deep resentment. This is due in part to the phenomenal growth of Yanacocha, from producing 81,000oz of gold in 1993 to 3,017,000oz last year. The town of Cajamarca has swelled from a population of 40,000 in 1990 to 240,000. House prices are soaring, traffic is heavy and there are problems with delinquency and prostitution.Yanacocha's story is far from unique. In February, Manhattan Minerals of Canada ditched plans for a $400m polymetallic mine at Tambogrande in the north, saying it could not find a senior partner because of protests against the project. Industry insiders say Tambogrande was poorly handled by an inexperienced company, but the most recent confrontation came at a project widely seen as a paradigm of best practice: BHP Billiton's Tintaya copper mine.The Anglo-Australian group won praise in December 2003 from both industry and such activist groups as Oxfam by signing an agreement with 37 local organisations, committing itself to give 3 per cent of its annual operating profits to the local community.But last week BHP was forced to suspend operations at Tintaya, Peru's third biggest copper mine, after protesters raided the site, demanding the company spend more on improving local roads. A government-led negotiating team is now trying to mediate.In Cajamarca, all sides agree that the tension can be resolved. Marco Arana, a Catholic priest and one of the leaders of the protests against Cerro Quilish, says the mercury spill need not leave an indelible mark on Yanacocha's record.“We could turn Choropampa into a model of environmental care, with a proper clean-up and good healthcare,” he says. “But if Newmont doesn't change, I fear there may be violence here.”

Titular: Mines dig deep for decent legacy
Texto: The controversy that for many years surrounded an Indonesian gold and copper mine operated by Freeport-McMoRan highlights many of the thorny issues faced by the mining industry. With millions of tons of debris generated by the Papua mine, Freeport has frequently been criticised by environmental campaigners.But another aspect of the mine - the fate of local communities after its eventual closure - is also proving hard for many mining companies to resolve. Not far from Freeport's Papua pits, for example, the once tiny village of Timika is now a small city."The problem is that companies don't get to choose where projects are, and they tend to be in the most depressed parts of the poorest countries," says Tim Mclaughlin, a consultant who has worked with both Freeport and Denver-based Newmont Mining. "And when you become the economic and social engine in an area, you attract people."The question for companies is how to ensure people attracted to the area continue to have livelihoods after mining operations have ceased. Shaun Stewart, international and government affairs adviser at Rio Tinto, the mining group, says: "We see it as a responsibility of ours that, when the mine closes down, we don't just leave a big hole in the ground - we leave a community that can sustain itself."One way in which the economic benefits of the mining business could be spread is through infrastructure development. The idea, says Mark Moody Stuart, chairman of Anglo American, is that when a mining company is developing the roads or ports associated with its business, its contractors could also develop infrastructure with wider use.Another answer is to foster businesses that can continue after mining operations have disappeared. This means sourcing locally wherever possible.Sir Mark cites the example of Anglo's operations in South Africa. "We have in the mines a company that started off by maintaining in-mine rail equipment," he says. "And they grow and go out and get non-mining business, so you're building capacity that originates in mining, but then is applicable to other areas of the economy."To encourage these businesses, the Anglo Zimele initiative - established by Anglo American in South Africa - provides loans to small businesses.Such approaches are not limited to the developing world. At Rio Tinto's Flambeau copper mine in Wisconsin, local businesses hoping to provide goods and services to the company were asked to produce a business plan demonstrating their sustainability beyond the life of the mine.Elsewhere, a research project by the International Council on Mining and Metals, which represents mining companies and associations, is examining how mineral wealth could be harnessed to reduce poverty and spread economic growth in developing countries. Focusing on Ghana and Peru, the project will identify "success factors" and highlight lessons for companies, non- governmental organisations, governments and others.Yet some NGOs suggest that companies should not meddle in such areas at all. Others point to the danger that such initiatives create yet another layer of dependence for communities.However, Mr Stewart believes such concerns can be addressed by consulting communities before starting development projects and by forming partnerships with local authorities and NGOs. "What we're always trying to do is hook the provincial government in," he says. Rio Tinto, he adds, might pay for the construction and equipping of a clinic and fund training for nurses, "but their salaries are paid by the government".However, some critics still believe corporate initiatives do not go far enough. "Mining companies have to be more transparent about the long-term impact of their operations," says Keith Slack, a senior policy adviser at Oxfam America. "They also have to build relations with the communities or they're going to have problems down the road - and that will start to impact the bottom line."For the previous article in this series click here

Titular: Wall Street lower as economy worries persist
Texto: Wall Street retreated on Tuesday amid signs of declining consumer confidence, worries about the rising price of oil and the sliding dollar's impact on economic growth.As news of slightly higher third-quarter economic growth was shrugged off, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was 0.4 per cent off at 10,428.02 by the close, while the S&P 500 shed 0.4 per cent to 1,173.82 and the Nasdaq Composite gave up 0.5 per cent at 2,096.81.The indices gave ground throughout the day and attempts at gaining it back failed as some traders warned the markets were at a vital juncture that would decide the fate of the current rally. Arthur Cashin, managing director at UBS, said it was "time to put up or shut up, resume the rally by starting a new up-leg or risk rolling over and giving back all the gains".The two sides of a "major battle" that Mr Cashin predicted consist of bullish traders pinning hopes on historical trends supporting a year-end rally, while on the other side less-sanguine voices noted that history and the calendar had not been reliable recently and that the outlook for markets remained clouded by uncertainties.In a heavy week for economic data the US government reported that third-quarter GDP grew 3.9 per cent, slightly higher than the earlier estimate of 3.7 per cent. The data failed to boost the fortunes of the dollar, which touched a new record low against the euro amid concern about Tuesday's other significant data report, on consumer confidence.The index of consumer confidence fell to 90.5 in November from 92.9 in October, well below expectations. The Conference Board, a business research group that compiles the index, said the data reflected that "[US] consumers do not feel the economy is likely to gain major momentum in early 2005". Ian Shepherdson, chief US economist at High Frequency Economics, said the data were "not great" but cautioned against using them to forecast US consumption in the Christmas shopping season, which was vital for retailers. "As always [it is] better to watch what people do than what they say."Retailers continued to be in focus as the Christmas shopping season got under way. Hot Topic shares fell 13.1 per cent to $16.37 after the clothing retailer trimmed its fourth-quarter guidance.Wal-Mart shares were down 2.1 per cent to $52.06 after reports that the world's biggest retailer, which cut its November sales forecast, had not implemented as aggressive discounts as its rivals.Away from retail, manufacturing activity in the US midwest appeared to be on the increase after the Chicago purchasing managers' index rose. Meanwhile, Nymex crude futures rose above $50 per barrel amid concern about supplies of petroleum products in the US.In corporate news, the shares of Google were up 0.5 per cent to $181.98 after the internet search company said it would buy back 23.4m shares from its employees.Also among technology stocks, Micromuse shares added 5.2 per cent to $5.25 after the software company reported one of its products had been chosen by Japan's NTT Communications.Loudeye, a digital media company, saw its shares add 16.4 per cent to $1.92 after it announced a deal with a partnership of several technology and cable television companies.Sybase, meanwhile, saw shares ease 1.3 per cent to $17.23 after the company announced a partnership with International Business Machines. IBM shares edged off 1.3 per cent to $94.24.Among commodity-related stocks, Newmont Mining shares lost 3.8 per cent to $47.35 after Indonesian prosecutors announced they would press charges against six executives at the company due to a pollution case.Syneron Medical shares lost 27.3 per cent to $27.05 by the close after the company's cellulite treatment was denied approval for marketing by US regulators.In the medical devices sector, Given Imaging shares rose 2.5 per cent to $33.31 after regulators approved its pill-shaped camera that provides images of the intestine in a less invasive manner than current procedures.Taser International shares charged 7.8 per cent higher to $27.08 following a third stock split this year by the maker of stun guns used by law enforcement agencies. Sales of the guns have risen sharply, even as their safety has come under scrutiny, most recently by Amnesty International.

Titular: Gold Fields bid may pave the way for consolidation
Texto: When South African gold producer Harmony announced its surprise plan to take over bigger rival Gold Fields in Johannesburg on Monday, Bernard Swanepoel, Harmony's chief executive, was asked a question about one of Goldfield's mines.
