Mr Swanepoel shot back: “Look, I'm not buying a room - I'm buying the hotel.”Mr Swanepoel's swagger is par for the course in an industry known for macho deal-makers. Over the nine years that Mr Swanepoel has been chief executive of South Africa's biggest domestic gold producer, the 43-year-old has gained recognition for his company's flair for extracting value from distressed mines.But Harmony's bid for Gold Fields, the world's fourth largest gold producer, surprised the markets with its boldness. Harmony, which built its reputation on turing round marginal South African mines, is smaller than Gold Fields, with few international operations.If accepted by Gold Fields' shareholders, the merger would create the world's largest gold producer by production, and the second-largest by market capitalisation, just behind Newmont of the US. It could also spark a round of mergers and acquisitions in an industry where analysts say there is room for more consolidation. “The other gold miners are not going to be happy to see this happen, as size is everything in this industry,” says John Meyer, mining analyst at Numis Securities in London.At the weekend Harmony firmed up its proposal by enlisting disgruntled Gold Fields shareholder Norilsk Nickel, Russia's largest nickel and palladium producer, controlled by Vladimir Potanin, the Russian oligarch. The offer to swap Harmony's shares for Gold Fields', if accepted by both company's shareholders, would torpedo a plan by Gold Fields' management to merge with mid-sized Canadian producer Iamgold.But Harmony's proposal may have a powerful opponent in Gold Fields' board, led by Ian Cockerill, its chief executive. Mr Cockerill on Monday called Harmony's overture a plan “that purports to be a merger when in fact it's a hostile takeover”. If Gold Fields' board, which was set to decide on the merger late on Monday, follows Mr Cockerill's lead in opposing the deal, Harmony's offer to shareholders can officially be termed hostile.Mr Swanepoel's aggressive move on another company's shareholders is reminiscent of tactics pioneered by the “Randlords” - the free-wheeling capitalists who built South Africa's mining industry a century ago, among them Cecil Rhodes, Gold Fields' founder. It may mark the beginning of a rare hostile takeover attempt of a leading company in the gold market. When talking to analysts, shareholders and journalists on Monday, Mr Swanepoel derided Gold Fields' proposed merger with Iamgold as “value leakage”. His offer, he said, was “good for Gold Fields and better than the current amount on the table for the Iamgold transaction”.The adage that “bigger is better” can arguably be applied to gold. The gold market is still fragmented, especially when compared with the iron ore industry where three companies control 80 per cent of seaborne trade. There has been some consolidation in the gold industry in recent years - such as AngloGold's purchase of Ashanti earlier this year and Newmont's acquisition of Australia's Normandy in early 2002 - but analysts expect to see many more mergers and acquisitions.New gold companies are forming all the time, attracted by rising precious-metals prices. But many of these junior names are speculators and are years away from dig a mine. Aim, London's stock market for small companies, has been a particular beneficiary of this modern-day gold rush, and has seen a stream of new listings and companies tapping the markets for funds. Investment bankers have been pitching M&A ideas to mining executives since early last year, when it became clear that commodities prices, after several years in the doldrums, were on the rise again. Harmony's attempt to secure Gold Fields may mean that the bankers' suggestions are being taken seriously by executives who are concerned about being left behind in the latest round of M&A activity. Canada's Placer Dome and Australia's Newcrest are among the gold producing companies on many bankers' lips as possible M&A targets.A successful Harmony/Gold Fields merger could widen the gap in the gold sector between the large and smaller companies with Harmony/Goldfields, Newmont and AngloGold Ashanti as industry leaders while former big hitters such as Barrick of Canada would be relegated to the middle, along with Placer Dome of Canada and Newcrest of Australia.Among the companies often cited as a potential takeover target is Newcrest, which market rumours have linked to Harmony and AngloGold Ashanti. Buyers had been put off the Australian group by its messy hedging strategy, but the imminent opening of its Telfer gold and copper mine in Western Australia is expected to attract renewed interest from potential suitors. The company's shares rose on Monday, on news of the possible Harmony/Gold Fields tie-up.Harmony had had its eye on Gold Fields for some time. But rumours last week - which later proved false - that Norilsk was planning its own bid for Gold Fields, pushed Mr Swanepoel to act. Harmony is offering Gold Fields' shareholders its shares at a 1:1.275 ratio. The proposed deal values Gold Fields at $8.1bn and would give shareholders a 29 per cent premium over Gold Fields' weighted average share price over the past month.The transaction has the blessing of Norilsk Nickel, which bought 20 per cent of Gold Fields in March and on Saturday formally committed itself to Harmony's offer. A condition of the bid going ahead is for Gold Fields to scrap a $2.1bn merger plan with mid-sized Canadian producer Iamgold.Norilsk on Monday confirmed publicly for the first time that it was backing Harmony in its bid. “Having studied the deal between Gold Fields and Iamgold, announced in August, and the proposal from Harmony, the management of Norilsk Nickel decided that it would vote against the deal with Iamgold and in favour of Harmony's proposals,” Mikhail Prokhorov, the company's chief executive said.Over the past two years Norilsk has been accumulating Russian gold assets, becoming the country's biggest gold producer, producing some 1m troy ounces a year. With gold assets worth $2.4bn, its Russian subsidiary Polyus alone last year made a net profit of $120m. But despite its expansion, Norilsk is still known for nickel and palladium. Its interest in Gold Fields is partly because the Russian company's market valuations remain much lower than those of gold producers.Norilsk picked up its 20 per cent stake in Gold Fields for R7.63bn ($1.2bn) in March in a surprise purchase from Anglo American. But its relationship with Gold Fields' management cooled after the South African company announced a proposal to merge with Iamgold. The proposal would see Gold Fields' international assets spun off into a separate listed company 30 per cent owned by Iamgold, effectively diluting Norilsk's exposure to the assets and leaving it with a stake in a smaller South African parent company. Norilsk had not been consulted about that possible deal.The proposed merger with Iamgold also angered some of Gold Fields' South African shareholders. Local investors, including groups representing black investors as part of South Africa's black empowerment drive and who increasingly own stakes in the mining industry, felt that the deal would amount to moving assets offshore, and that Gold Fields was offering too much for Iamgold. Harmony may be better able to appeal to the South African government, which is sensitive about capital flight, by saying the deal will keep assets within the country.Analysts say that Harmony's bid is also positive for Norilsk because it would re-open the opportunity for the Russian company to swap its gold assets for liquid shares in an international company. “As far as the market is concerned, the rationale for buying a 20 per cent stake in Gold Fields in the first place was to allow Interros - the holding company that controls Norilsk - to gain liquid shares in a foreign company by rolling Norilsk's gold assets into it,” says Al Breach, chief strategist at Moscow's Brunswick UBS. This would have been hard to achieve under the proposed merger with Iamgold.Harmony's move would also give Mr Potanin exposure to a bigger foreign company amid growing state intervention in Russia's economy. As Andrei Illarionov, Russian president Vladimir Putin's economic adviser, recently told the FT: “Over the past several years, a near-consensus has emerged that natural resources should belong to the state - not to private citizens and private companies, but the state.”Mr Potanin cannot sell his metals and mining assets to a foreign company. Swapping them for a larger stake in Gold Fields, however, may be more palatable to the Kremlin. “Anglo American and Rio Tinto have been acquiring assets all over the world,” says Alexander Pukhaev, metals and mining analyst at Moscow-based United Financial Group. “Just because companies like Norilsk Nickel are in Russia does not mean that they are not going to be doing the same.”With Norilsk on board, Harmony must now sell its vision to the company's other shareholders, most of whom are in Britain and the US. Company executives, including Mr Swanepoel, are due to take the proposal directly to them in what the chief executive calls “an intense marketing campaign”. Harmony has a proven record of turning around mature mining assets. Mr Swanepoel has led the company on an expansion drive, buying marginal mines from bigger rivals such as AngloGold and Gold Fields.However, this approach, which Mr Swanepoel calls “the Harmony Way”, has come under pressure over the past year. With about 90 per cent of its assets in South Africa, the company has suffered more than most South African mining companies due to the strong rand. Harmony's less profitable mines have suffered the most, and over the past several months the company has reported weak earnings and had to cut thousands of jobs.Gold Fields, by contrast, has a third of its production outside South Africa but derives two-thirds of its operating profit from foreign operations, mostly in Australia and Ghana, and has exploration and development projects around the world. The profile makes Gold Fields an alluring target.Industry insiders were uncertain on Monday whether Harmony would succeed in winning control of Gold Fields. “At first we thought it was laughable, with similarities to Randgold's bid for Ashanti last year,” said one London-based mining analyst. “But the more we look at it the more we think it has legs and is credible,” he added. Working against Harmony's bid, analysts said, are the fact that its mines are lower quality than Gold Fields'.Gold Fields' shareholders have 30 days to respond to Harmony's offer. Mr Swanepoel is hoping to shore up support from the majority of shareholders before a December shareholders' meeting at which Mr Cockerill had planned to win endorsement for the Iamgold deal. Harmony will ask its own shareholders to approve its rival merger proposal at an extraordinary general meeting on November 12.Harmony calculates that it needs a 15 per cent cost reduction on Gold Fields' South African assets to justify the premium it is offering shareholders. “Gold Fields is ripe for some cost-cutting and Harmony is well-known for its cost-cutting abilities,” says Mr Meyer of Numis Securities in London. As Mr Swanepoel's takes his offer on the road, Mr Cockerill and Gold Fields' other managers may have to watch their backs. Harmony's chief executive has mentioned “management overheads” as a potential source of cost cutting.Golden days are here again, for nowUnderlying current investment activity in the gold industry is the solid rise in gold prices over the past three years, and the belief among executives and shareholders that the good times will continue.Back in 2001, the low gold price kept many gold projects languishing. Geologists knew where the gold was, but miners knew it was not worth digging it up. Spending by the large miners on exploration and development of new projects had been slashed, and mining entrepreneurs - the industry’s backbone - could not get financial backing for their ventures. Investors were still concentrating on “new economy” growth stocks, despite the dotcom bust, and the commodity markets were considered passé.On top of investor indifference, central bank sales of gold reserves had also undermined the gold price. Uncertainty over central bank strategy and widespread forward selling by gold producers discouraged fund managers from looking at gold, which reached its lowest point in April 2001.While productivity of gold mines and demand for jewellery are the main factors governing the physical supply of and demand for gold, they have relatively little influence on its price, say analysts. “Supply and demand move too slowly. It is changes at the margins, such as investment and central bank sales, that really move the market,” says Neil Meader, senior analyst at precious metals consultancy GFMS.Since 2001, these factors have swung back into gold’s favour. Central banks have finished selling gold and gold producers are no longer selling forward or hedging. The weakening of the dollar also helped the gold price as the metal has traditionally traded in the opposite direction to the US currency. Cyclical investments have come back into fashion over the last three years and commodities have been among the best performers, buoyed by demand for precious and base metals from growing economies such as China and India.Hedge funds and other speculators were quick to spot the recovery in the commodities market, particularly in gold. These funds were blamed when the gold price fell dramatically earlier this year, from a peak of around $428 an ounce in April to around $375 an ounce in May. It was widely assumed that speculators were taking some of their profits following a good run in the gold price. Volatility in energy prices had also distracted speculators, who saw a better opportunity for making a quick buck. Analysts expect the gold price to suffer whenever there are large movements in the oil price.The gold price is now trading close to $420 an ounce, having regained much of the ground lost in May. But crucially, the mood in the gold industry remains more positive than it has been for years. Predictions that the gold price will stay above $400 for some time are encouraging companies such as Norilsk, already doing well in nickel and platinum, to expand into gold. New junior mining companies, many of them years away from actually producing gold, have raised money on London’s alternative stock market, Aim, as well as in Australia and Canada.This year the fixtures on the mining industry’s conference circuit reflected this optimism. At a major annual gold industry gathering in Toronto in March, exhibitors had to set up in the corridors of an over-crowded conference centre. At the MinExpo mining equipment jamboree in Las Vegas last month, suppliers of drills and diggers, such as Caterpillar, were rubbing their hands at the thought of rising orders from prospectors. All involved know that the market is cyclical and that lean times are never that far away, but for now they are happy to join the gold rush.

Titular: Study to clear Newmont of pollution charges
Texto: Levels of mercury and arsenic in an Indonesian bay into which Newmont, the world?s largest gold producer, dumped waste until the end of August fall within internationally acceptable levels, according to a new government study due to be released on Tuesday.However, Indonesian police said Monday they planned to continue pursuing environmental charges against six Newmont managers, five of whom have been detained for almost a month in connection with the case.The finding marks a significant step in the controversy surrounding Newmont?s Minahasa Raya mine in North Sulawesi, which has been at the centre of pollution allegations for years.Newmont said Monday night that the report ?represents complete vindication? for its practices in Buyat Bay, where residents claim waste from the mine caused health problems and the depletion of local fisheries.?We strongly believe the information contained in this report - verified by six government and private accredited laboratories - should put to rest the controversy regarding Buyat Bay,? said Tom Enos, Newmont?s vice president of international operations.But Indonesian police said they are standing by laboratory tests showing elevated levels of both arsenic and mercury in the bay, despite widespread criticism that the test was flawed.The case against Newmont has become the latest example of Indonesia?s often fraught climate for foreign investors.It has also become a key test for the mining industry and the way it disposes of its treated waste mining material.According to the new report by a joint government team working under Indonesia?s environment ministry the levels of arsenic and mercury in both Buyat Bay?s water and its fish fell within internationally acceptable levels - despite 2,000 tonnes a day of treated waste being poured into the bay for the past eight years.The study did find elevated concentrations of arsenic in the sediment at the end of a pipe via which Newmont dumped its tailings. However, the report said, ?it appears that the arsenic in the sediment is in a stable form?.Other problems were also found in the area that did not appear to be the result of Newmont?s operations, including a ?high? concentration of mercury in the sediment of Ratatotok Bay, the bay next to Buyat Bay.The ?most likely source? for that mercury pollution, the report?s authors said, was ?small scale? or illegal gold mining operations in the area.Additional reporting by Taufan Hidayat

Titular: Indonesia to pass Newmont case to prosecutors
Texto: Indonesian police are expected to pass a controversial pollution case against executives of US-based Newmont, the world?s largest gold producer, to prosecutors on Thursday, setting the stage for a possible criminal trial.The six Newmont managers - including two Americans and an Australian - were detained earlier this month as suspects.Police plan to hand the case to prosecutors in North Sulawesi, the location of Newmont?s Minahasa Raya mine, a move that in the Indonesian justice system equates to laying charges against a suspect.Lawsuits against foreign companies are common in Indonesia but it is rare for overseas executives to be detained for extended periods or charged.The case against Newmont - which hinges on claims that tailings from the Minahasa Raya mine caused chronic illness among villagers living in the area, has become a litmus test for Indonesia?s troubled investment climate.Key evidence in the case is in dispute - independent experts from groups including the World Health Organisation argue there is little evidence of pollution in the bay into which Newmont dumped tailings until August.But police claim their tests show that the bay?s waters contain unhealthy levels of mercury and arsenic.?Those six suspects have committed a corporate crime,? Brigadier General Suharto, the investigator in charge of the case said.The company?s local chief executive and the five other managers face up to 10 years in prison if convicted, he said.Newmont has claimed throughout that it has done nothing wrong.The miner argues it never used mercury in its extraction process at Minahasa Raya. Any elevated levels of naturally-occurring arsenic and mercury in the tailings were reduced to acceptable levels by special ?scrubbers? before the slurry was released into the bay almost a kilometre from shore, company officials claim.In an August 26 report prepared for the World Health Organisation, Japanese mercury poisoning experts said levels of the metal in the bay were within acceptable international guidelines.Tests also indicated the villagers had normal levels of mercury in their blood for populations that eat a lot of fish.In fact, the bigger environmental issue in the area of the mine, the WHO experts concluded, was in the bay next door where they conducted tests as a control. There, mercury levels were ?much higher? thanks to hundreds of small-scale illegal gold miners who for decades have used mercury to extract gold and dumped their waste into a river that flows into the bay, they said.Additional reporting by Taufan Hidayat

Titular: NMC scandal proves a boon for global advisers
Subtitular: The UAE-based healthcare group’s troubles have amplified concerns about local regulators
Texto: It took four decades for NMC Health to ascend from its humble origins as a small clinic founded by Indian entrepreneur BR Shetty to its pinnacle as a FTSE 100 favourite.It took less than four months for the success story of the largest private healthcare provider in the United Arab Emirates to sour after short-sellers questioned NMC’s debt and cash position last December. Angry denials quickly collapsed as an independent investigation triggered a series of damaging revelations that saw NMC admit evidence of fraud and more than $4bn of undisclosed debt.Earlier this month, NMC’s major creditor, Abu Dhabi Commercial Bank (ADCB), successfully applied to a UK court to place the London-listed business in administration. Restructuring consultancy Alvarez & Marsal has taken over management of the hospitals and clinics, replacing the entire board.“Clearly something has gone very wrong with the management and oversight of this company,” said Judge Sebastian Prentis at the hearing.The unfurling scandal has been lucrative for consultants, with boutique investment banks coming in to advise the company’s management, shareholders and creditors.The appointment of Alvarez & Marsal to handle the UK administration comes after the previous management brought in investment bank Moelis & Co and accountancy firm PwC to assist them with debt restructuring and operational advice as NMC sought a debt standstill. Shareholders, such as Mr Shetty, have also engaged their own advisers, including investment bank Houlihan Lokey, to steer them through the situation.The crisis at the UAE’s largest private healthcare provider has coincided with the onset of the coronavirus pandemic. “The turmoil at NMC couldn’t come at a worse time given the growing Covid-19 crisis,” says one healthcare consultant. The number of cases had risen by Wednesday to more than 5,300, with 33 deaths.The Gulf state has introduced tight restrictions on movement, with Dubai imposing a 24-hour curfew that requires residents to apply for a permit to leave their homes to collect essentials. A mass testing programme has involved opening 13 drive-through testing centres across the seven-emirate federation, as well as the construction of a laboratory in Abu Dhabi that can assess tens of thousands of samples a day.While some non-essential NMC facilities have closed because of the nationwide lockdown, one person close to the company says any hospital and clinic that can serve patients is staying open. NMC has more than 2,200 beds and 2,000 doctors in 200 facilities across the UAE.The company’s former management attempted to block the administration effort, arguing that such a move would destabilise the business at a critical juncture. Alvarez & Marsal quickly wrote to assure staff that the administrators would strive to allow medical staff to deliver healthcare efficiently, including a commitment to pay salaries on time. NMC struggled to meet February payroll.Clearly something has gone very wrong with the management and oversight of this companySome local healthcare executives believe that the government would have intervened if it feared a shortage of intensive care beds. As it is, Dubai alone already has up to 5,000 available for Covid-19 patients and can handle more than 10,000 with the construction of two field hospitals. It also plans to convert deserted hotels into medical facilities if the need arises.“The government has a full handle on the number of intensive care beds needed,” says one healthcare executive. “If they needed the hospitals, they would have acted differently on NMC.”Alvarez’s three joint administrators working on NMC are all senior managers based in the UK, rather than in the consultancy’s UAE office. In a letter to staff, Richard Fleming, managing director of Alvarez & Marsal Europe, said this was because NMC is registered in the UK.At the administration hearing, the judge expressed his confidence that the new management, backed by fresh funding, would be able to keep NMC a going concern. ADCB has pledged to provide new working capital facilities.Yet the scandal has once again tarnished the UAE’s reputation as a commercial centre. Coming less than two years after the fall of Abraaj — a Dubai-based private equity group that collapsed when it was accused of misusing investor money — it has intensified concerns about local regulators’ capacity to deal with such complex cases.Abraaj started to unravel when overseas investors in the group’s healthcare fund raised the alarm on its alleged use of their money for internal purposes, rather than investments. Alissa Amico Kole, managing director of the Govern Center, which advises on corporate governance, points out that the original whistleblower on NMC’s financial problems — research firm Muddy Waters — also came from outside the region.To bolster local ability to handle such crises, Nasser Saidi, a governance consultant, says the financial regulator’s powers could be expanded into a supervisory body to screen regional companies seeking to list abroad. He also believes that a UAE version of the UK’s Companies House — providing information on corporate ownership and financials to the public — would benefit transparency.While the Abraaj scandal damaged the fundraising prospects of the Middle Eastern private equity industry, NMC threatens to do likewise for UAE companies seeking to access the deep pools of capital in western markets.“The level of scrutiny for companies from here will be off the charts,” says one investment banker.

Titular: US protests Jakarta?s action on Newmont
Texto: The US government on Friday protested the detention in Jakarta of six executives from Newmont Mining on environmental charges, saying the move could ?only harm? an already fragile investment climate for foreign investors in Indonesia.A dispute between Newmont of the US and environmental groups over the state of the water in a bay near its Minahasa Raya mine in northern Sulawesi and what is responsible for health problems amongst local villagers has escalated in recent days.Police late on Thursday released Richard Ness, the gold miner?s local chief executive, after detaining him for three hours. But they brought Mr Ness, an American, in for further questioning on Friday.Five other Newmont managers - three Indonesians, an Australian, and a US citizen remained in police detention Friday night, charged with environmental crimes.Indonesian police claim their tests and other evidence given to them by experts show the waters in the bay near the mine have elevated levels of arsenic and mercury and that Newmont is responsible.The executives each face up to five years in prison if they are convicted of the charges being levelled against them.But Newmont says its tests of samples taken at the same time as by the police show nothing of the sort.Other independent tests also indicate no pollution has taken place in the bay, the company claims.The US embassy in Jakarta said Friday night the detention of the Newmont staff was ?inappropriate? as Newmont had ?fully cooperated? with Indonesian authorities and ?guaranteed their continued cooperation?.?The detention of Newmont employees under these circumstances can only harm the investment climate in Indonesia,? the embassy said.Indonesia has suffered a dearth of foreign direct investment in sectors such as mining in recent years causing the economy to lag its Asian neighbours.
